answer: To pursue a career in Software Engineering, typically, you would require a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, Information Technology, or a related field. Some universities offer Software Engineering degrees with a foundation year for students without prior programming experience.  In terms of foundational requirements, a strong background in mathematics, particularly in areas such as algebra, calculus, and statistics, is beneficial. Additionally, having a good understanding of programming concepts, data structures, algorithms, and computer architecture is essential.  Furthermore, soft skills such as problem-solving abilities, communication skills, teamwork, and adaptability are highly valued in the software engineering profession.  It's also worth noting that many employers prefer candidates who have completed internships or have practical experience in software development during their studies.  At Nottingham Trent University, they offer a Software Engineering degree program that accepts students from various academic backgrounds and provides all the necessary help and support to develop coding skills. They also offer a Software Engineering degree with a foundation year for those without prior programming experience.

ground_truth: The academic qualifications required for a career in software engineering include a Bachelor of Science (Honours) in Software Engineering, which can be obtained with or without completing a foundation year. Additionally, having a background in Mathematics and Data Science could also be beneficial due to their relevance in the field.

A Safe and Secure Driving System to Mitigate Remote Vehicle Hijacking Risks. The system focuses on:The development of a secure vehicular communication system considering physical layer and protocol level security as well as network segmentation approach.

Metadata: Projects

Text:

The Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG) has several active projects that include:



Drive with Confidence

LiNET-Visible Light Secure Networking for Connected Vehicles: The LiNET project is targeting to innovate visible light communication-enabled networking framework for enabling CAV traffic environments. Building on our existing research on connected vehicles, this team will focus on developing a

Cyber Security for Smart EV Charging Network: The core objective of the E-Mobility Cyber Security project is to foster NTU-Industry research collaboration toward EV-centric smart, secure, and green mobility. The expertise-centric research collaboration consists of three working groups including
answer: The key components and objectives of a secure vehicular communication system in mitigating remote vehicle hijacking risks include:  1. Secure vehicular communication system: This involves implementing physical layer and protocol level security measures, as well as network segmentation approaches to ensure secure communication between vehicles and other entities. 2. In-vehicle intrusion detection system: This system uses artificial intelligence to monitor the vehicle's network for suspicious activity, such as attempts to connect to the vehicle's control systems from unauthorized connections or devices. 3. Development of a secure vehicular communication framework: The LiNET project aims to innovate a visible light communication-enabled networking framework for enabling connected vehicles in traffic environments. This includes developing secure communication protocols and mechanisms to protect against potential threats. 4. Collaboration with industry partners: The E-Mobility Cyber Security project fosters research collaboration with industry partners towards the development of secure, smart, and green electric vehicle charging networks. This collaboration aims to address cybersecurity challenges specific to electric vehicles and their charging infrastructure.
contexts:
["A Safe and Secure Driving System to Mitigate Remote Vehicle Hijacking Risks. The system focuses on:The development of a secure vehicular communication system considering physical layer and protocol level security as well as network segmentation approach.

Integrating an in-vehicle intrusion detection system using artificial intelligence to monitor the vehicle's network for suspicious activity, such as attempts to connect to the vehicle's control systems from an unauthorised connection or device.



PRAVE Project (PRoactive Authentication and Verification Embedded Model for Critical Cyber-Physical Systems). This Research and Development project will innovate a new proactive security model for protecting cyber-physical systems in the CNI using a trustworthy artificial intelligent approach. PRAVE will focus on proactive authentication and verification protocol with the involvement of some of the physical aspects from the connected smart things within the CNI."]
ground_truth: The key components and objectives of a secure vehicular communication system to mitigate remote vehicle hijacking risks include developing a secure vehicular communication system that considers physical layer and protocol level security, as well as implementing network segmentation. Additionally, integrating an in-vehicle intrusion detection system using artificial intelligence is crucial for monitoring the vehicle's network for suspicious activity such as unauthorized connections or devices attempting to access control systems.

ground_truth: AI intrusion detection contributes to preventing unauthorized vehicle control within the Safe and Secure Driving System by monitoring the vehicle's network for suspicious activity. This includes detecting attempts to connect from unauthorized devices or connections, which could indicate an attempt at remote hijacking. By identifying such threats early, the system can take appropriate measures to maintain control over the vehicle and ensure safety.

answer: In the BSc (Hons) Data Science program at NTU, computational intelligence plays a significant role in preparing students for real-world scenarios and industrial applications. The program emphasizes the practical application of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning, and cognitive computing in various industries. Students gain hands-on experience by working on real-world projects, focusing on the industrial application of computational intelligence. This practical experience, combined with the technical nature of the course, equips students to actively engage in industrial, commercial, and scientific computing, thereby preparing them for successful careers in data science.

Itâ€™s a hands-on way of learning that will develop your problem solving and creative thinking skills and helps to build other transferable skills such as team-working. At NTU, we understand that big data, machine learning, and artificial intelligence are transforming industries. That's why our goal is to equip you with the skills and knowledge to become an expert in data science. Using a diverse set of statistical, algorithmic, and predictive tools, you will gain the ability to transform raw data into practical and actionable information,", 'information, capable of predicting trends and driving outcomes. Are you ready to take on the challenges presented by big data and artificial intelligence? Our curriculum will empower you to develop data-driven solutions that optimize business processes, as well as harness the power of data to support human decision-making. But our approach goes beyond theory. You will have hands-on experience, applying your knowledge in real-world scenarios with a focus on the industrial application of computational intelligence. This practical experience, combined with the technical nature of our course, will prepare you to actively engage in industrial, commercial, scientific, and technological research and development of intelligent systems. If you find data science isnâ€™t for you, we can support you to move into one of our other computer science courses at the end of your foundation year.']
ground_truth: Computational intelligence plays a significant role in the BSc (Hons) Data Science program at NTU by providing hands-on experience that allows students to apply their knowledge in real-world scenarios. This practical approach focuses on the industrial application of computational intelligence, preparing students to engage in research and development of intelligent systems across various sectors such as industry, commerce, science, and technology.

answer: In the BSc (Hons) Data Science (with foundation year) program at Nottingham Trent University, students focus on foundational subjects such as programming, mathematics, and engineering during their first-year foundation program. This prepares them to move onto BSc (Hons) Data Science in their second year. answer: NTU's BSc (Hons) Data Science program aims to equip students with a strong foundation in computer science, enabling them to extract valuable insights from large datasets. Specifically, the program focuses on developing skills in programming, mathematics (including linear algebra, probability and statistics, discrete mathematics), artificial intelligence, database engineering, and data analysis. Additionally, students will learn about machine learning algorithms, data visualization, and statistical modeling. The program also emphasizes the importance of ethical considerations in working with data and AI technologies.

answer: The Data Science BSc (Hons) program at NTU aims to equip students with a variety of skills and knowledge to become experts in data science. These include:  1. Programming skills: Students will learn various programming languages such as Python, Java, and SQL, which are essential for data analysis and manipulation.  2. Mathematics and statistics: A strong foundation in mathematics and statistics is crucial for understanding and interpreting data. Topics covered may include linear algebra, probability, and statistical methods.  3. Data analysis and visualization: Students will learn how to analyze large datasets, identify patterns, and present findings effectively using tools like Tableau, Matlab, and R.  4. Machine learning and artificial intelligence: Students will gain hands-on experience with machine learning algorithms, neural networks, and deep learning techniques to build predictive models and solve complex problems.  5. Big data management: Students will learn how to manage, store, and process large volumes of data efficiently using databases, cloud platforms, and distributed computing systems.  6. Ethics and responsible data practices: As data scientists, students will be expected to understand and adhere to ethical guidelines when working with data, ensuring privacy, security, and fairness in their analyses.  7. Communication and teamwork: Effective communication and collaboration are vital in the data science field. Students will have opportunities to work in teams on real-world projects, presenting their findings to peers and industry professionals.  8. Industry-relevant projects: Throughout the program, students will work on industry-relevant projects, gaining practical experience and developing a portfolio of work that showcases their skills and abilities.  By the end of the program, students should be able to apply their skills and knowledge to real-world data science problems, making informed decisions based on data analysis and interpretation. They will be prepared to pursue careers in various sectors, including technology, finance, healthcare, and government.

answer: The BSc (Hons) Data Science curriculum at NTU prepares students for industrial applications of computational intelligence through several key components:  1. Solid Mathematical Foundation: Students learn essential mathematical concepts that form the basis for understanding complex data structures and algorithms used in data science.  2. Skills Development: The course equips students with practical skills relevant to the modern world, including the use of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning, and cognitive computing.  3. Hands-On Experience: Students gain practical experience by applying their knowledge in real-world scenarios, focusing on the industrial application of computational intelligence.  4. Focus on Industrial Application: The curriculum emphasizes the practical aspects of data science, preparing students to actively engage in industrial, commercial, scientific, and technological research and development of intelligent systems.  5. Portfolio Development: Students develop a portfolio showcasing their skills and knowledge gained throughout the course, which can be presented to potential employers.  6. Technical Nature of the Course: The technical nature of the course ensures that students are well-equipped to handle the challenges posed by AI and big data in various industries.  7. Emphasis on Big Data, Machine Learning, and AI: The curriculum is designed to help students understand and leverage these transformative technologies in industries.  8. Accreditation Requirements: The course meets the accreditation requirements of BCS – the Institute for IT, for both CITP and partial CEng registration, ensuring that students receive a well-recognized qualification.

As a parent or carer of a prospective NTU student, how should I help them prepare for university life? Parents/carers of students with disabilities and learning differences play a vital role in preparing them for university life and supporting them throughout their studies. Support is very
answer: Parents or guardians can help their young students develop essential life skills like cooking, budgeting, and supermarket shopping in preparation for university life by:  1. Encouraging independence: Allow your child to take responsibility for meal planning, grocery shopping, and cooking meals at home. This will help build confidence and independence. 2. Teaching basic cooking skills: Show your child how to cook simple meals, such as pasta dishes, sandwiches, and stir-fries. As they become more confident, introduce more complex recipes. 3. Budgeting: Help your child create a budget for groceries and other expenses. Discuss the importance of sticking to a budget and making wise financial decisions. 4. Supermarket shopping: Take your child shopping with you and encourage them to compare prices, read labels, and make informed choices. 5. Cooking together: Cooking together as a family can be a fun way to teach your child cooking skills while spending quality time together. 6. Setting realistic expectations: Understand that your child may not be an expert chef or budget planner overnight. Be patient and offer guidance as needed. 7. Practicing budgeting exercises: Have your child practice creating a budget for a week or month, and then review it together to discuss any areas that need improvement. 8. Encourage saving: Teach your child the importance of saving money for emergencies or future expenses, such as textbooks or travel costs. 9. Teach meal planning: Help your child plan meals for the week, considering factors such as cost, nutrition, and convenience. 10. Practice cooking independently: Give your child opportunities to cook meals independently, either at home or in a kitchen at school or university.
contexts: ["As a parent or guardian of a prospective student, what type of practical things could I be doing to help my young person prepare for university life? It's never too early to start nurturing independent living skills such as: cooking, budgeting, supermarket shopping, personal hygiene, getting up in the morning, working washing machines, programming central heating, taking out the rubbish, travelling to university from their accommodation, give the student every opportunity to take responsibility for these tasks. Lack of independent living skills is all too often the reason that a student will struggle in their first year of university and this can have a huge impact on their studies."]
ground_truth: Parents or guardians can assist their young students in developing essential life skills such as cooking, budgeting, and supermarket shopping by nurturing independent living skills. This includes teaching them how to cook meals, manage a budget effectively, shop for groceries at the supermarket, maintain personal hygiene, wake up on time, operate household appliances like washing machines, program central heating systems, and handle tasks such as taking out the rubbish. Additionally, they can provide opportunities for students to practice these skills by encouraging them to take responsibility for these tasks. Developing these independent living skills is crucial in preparing a student for university life, where lack of such skills can negatively impact their studies.

Metadata: Guide

Text:

SUPPORT LIKE NO OTHER

At NTU, we feel parents and carers have a very important role to play in supporting the journey into university. Many parents and carers want to know what they can do to support that transition, so we have provided this information to get you started. We want to work together to ensure the time

them to consider all the options and make a decision that is right for them. Many of our students find that living at home, at least for the first year, gives them the best chance to get used to university study without having to get used to independent living at the same time. Choosing a course
answer: Some key topics to discuss with your prospective student regarding accommodation options before they arrive at NTU include:  1. Living at Home: Discuss the benefits of living at home during their first year, such as financial savings, familiar surroundings, and reduced stress from adjusting to independent living. 2. University Halls: Explore the option of living in university halls, which offer a great opportunity to meet new people, make budgeting easier due to included utility bills, and provide a supportive environment for students new to university life. 3. Course Alignment: Encourage your student to choose a course that aligns with their interests and career goals, as this will help them stay motivated and engaged throughout their studies. 4. Budgeting: Help your student create a budget for their accommodation and living expenses, taking into account tuition fees, rent, utilities, food, and other costs. 5. Accommodation Types: Discuss the various types of accommodation available at NTU, including halls, apartments, and houses, and help your student decide which option best suits their preferences and needs. 6. Location: Consider the location of the accommodation in relation to the university campus, amenities, public transportation, and personal safety. 7. Support Services: Discuss the support services available to students living off-campus, such as pastoral care, academic advice, and mental health resources. 8. Contract Terms: Review the terms of any accommodation contracts, including length of lease, deposit requirements, and cancellation policies. 9. Visiting the Accommodation: Arrange a visit to any potential accommodations to get a sense of the living conditions, facilities, and community atmosphere. 10. Making a Decision: Encourage your student to weigh the pros and cons of each accommodation option and make an informed decision based on their priorities and preferences.

It's never too early to start nurturing independent living skills such as: cooking, budgeting, supermarket shopping, personal hygiene, getting up in the morning, working washing machines, programming central heating, taking out the rubbish, travelling to university from their accommodation, give the student every opportunity to take responsibility for these tasks. Lack of independent living skills is all too often the reason that a student will struggle in their first year of university and this can have a huge impact on their studies.", "As a parent or guardian of a prospective student, what type of things do we need to talk about before my young person arrives at NTU? It would be useful to talk through some of the big decisions they need to make, such as course choice and accommodation options. Encourage them to consider all the options and make a decision that is right for them. Many of our students find that living at home, at least for the first year, gives them the best chance to get used to university study without having to get used to independent living at the same time. Choosing a course which suits them and is enjoyable matters, as it will reduce the inevitable pressures that arise in the process of securing a degree. Students with neurodiversities are often best served short-term and long-term when they follow their 'passions' and find a vocational niche within that area which can be nurtured."]
ground_truth: Before arriving at NTU, it is important to discuss various accommodation options with your prospective student. Considering the advantages of living at home for the first year, you can explore whether they would prefer staying in a shared house or dormitory near their university campus. Additionally, discuss how choosing a course that aligns with their interests might influence their choice of accommodation, as some courses may have specific housing requirements or recommendations.

As a parent or guardian of a prospective student, what type of things do we need to talk about before my young person arrives at NTU? It would be useful to talk through some of the big decisions they need to make, such as course choice and accommodation options. Encourage them to consider all the
answer: Parents or guardians can take several practical steps to help their teenage children develop essential independent living skills that will contribute to a successful transition and experience during their first year at university:  1. Cooking: Teach them basic cooking skills, meal planning, and grocery shopping. Encourage them to experiment with recipes and learn to cook meals for themselves. 2. Budgeting: Help them understand the cost of living expenses, including tuition fees, rent, utilities, food, transportation, and entertainment. Teach them how to create a budget, manage finances, and avoid overspending. 3. Personal Hygiene: Ensure they understand the importance of good personal hygiene, including showering regularly, brushing teeth, and maintaining clean clothes. 4. Getting Up in the Morning: Establish a consistent sleep schedule and routine to help them wake up on time each day. 5. Working Washing Machines: Show them how to operate a washing machine, dryer, and iron. Teach them how to sort laundry, read care labels, and properly hang or fold clothes. 6. Central Heating: Explain how to program and adjust the thermostat for optimal comfort while conserving energy. 7. Taking Out the Rubbish: Teach them how to dispose of household waste responsibly, including recycling and composting. 8. Travelling to University: Practice routes to the university, familiarize them with public transportation options, and discuss safety precautions. 9. Independent Living Skills: Provide opportunities for them to take on responsibilities such as cleaning their room, doing laundry, and managing their own schedules. 10. Problem Solving: Encourage them to seek solutions to problems independently, such as resolving conflicts with roommates or addressing academic difficulties.  By fostering independence and problem-solving skills, parents and guardians can help their teenage children develop the necessary skills for a successful transition to university life.
contexts: ["As a parent or guardian of a prospective student, what type of practical things could I be doing to help my young person prepare for university life? It's never too early to start nurturing independent living skills such as: cooking, budgeting, supermarket shopping, personal hygiene, getting up in the morning, working washing machines, programming central heating, taking out the rubbish, travelling to university from their accommodation, give the student every opportunity to take responsibility for these tasks. Lack of independent living skills is all too often the reason that a student will struggle in their first year of university and this can have a huge impact on their studies."]
ground_truth: Parents or guardians can assist in developing essential independent living skills for their teenage children by nurturing abilities such as cooking, budgeting, supermarket shopping, personal hygiene, waking up on time, operating household appliances like washing machines and central heating systems, managing rubbish disposal, and traveling to university from accommodation. These skills are crucial for a successful transition into university life as they promote responsibility and can significantly impact the student's academic performance during their first year.

What is the difference between MComp Computer Science and BSc Computer Science? MComp computer Science is an integrated Master's course. It includes one extra year of study after the completion of the BSc degree.

You have the option to transfer between the MComp degree and the BSc degree during the first two taught years of the course, subject to your performance and your chosen module in year two.

Text:

The course leader and year 3 tutor for Computer Science BSc (Hons) is Dr. Andrew Pierson, who is a Principal Lecturer in Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.
answer: The main difference between MComp Computer Science and BSc Computer Science courses lies in their structure and duration.  An MComp Computer Science is an integrated Master's course, meaning it includes one additional year of study after the completion of the BSc degree. This extra year provides more advanced and specialized topics compared to the BSc course.  In terms of structure, the MComp course builds upon the foundations established in the BSc degree and adds postgraduate-level material in the final year. There is an option to transfer between the MComp degree and the BSc degree during the first two taught years of the course, subject to your performance and your chosen module in year two.  If you perform well, there is also an opportunity to transfer to the four-year MComp (Hons) Computer Science course, which combines undergraduate and postgraduate material.  On the other hand, a BSc Computer Science typically takes three years to complete, focusing on foundational topics in computer science.  In summary, while both courses cover similar topics, the MComp course offers a more comprehensive and specialized education, taking four years to complete.

ground_truth: MComp Computer Science is an integrated Master's course that includes one extra year of study after completing the BSc degree. This means that the overall duration for MComp Computer Science is longer than that of a standard BSc Computer Science program, which typically concludes with the undergraduate degree.

Text:
answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), our Computing course is designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge that are highly relevant to today's technology landscape. Our curriculum emphasizes practical application, focusing on data-driven solutions, artificial intelligence, and interactive systems that are in high demand in industries.  Regarding changing a Computing course after starting it, it depends on the specific circumstances and the policies of the university. It may be possible to switch courses, but it would require careful consideration and consultation with academic advisors to ensure a smooth transition and minimize any potential loss of credits or time. I recommend reaching out to the University's Student Services team for guidance on this matter.

Can I change to a different course after I have started? It is even possible to move between some courses at the end of year one. Please consult the course leaders for more information."]
ground_truth: Nottingham Trent University offers very relevant Computing courses with a high rate of employment for graduates, excellent facilities to support course delivery, and student support throughout their studies. Students can change between some Computing courses at the end of term one or year one by consulting the course leaders.

answer: After submitting a UCAS application, the following steps are involved in applying for financial support and Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs):  1. Visit the official government website at www.gov.uk/studentfinance to apply for student finance and DSAs. 2. Fill out the online application form, providing necessary details such as personal information, course details, and financial information. 3. Submit supporting documents, including bank statements, proof of identity, and evidence of any disabilities or learning differences. 4. Wait for the Student Finance England to process the application and send a letter confirming the amount of funding available. 5. If eligible for DSAs, arrange for an assessment with a Needs Assessment Centre (NAC) to determine the specific support required. 6. Based on the results of the NAC assessment, a Needs Assessment Report (NAR) will be produced, detailing the recommended support. 7. Send the NAR to the university's Disability Service, along with any other relevant documentation. 8. Meet with a Disability Advisor at the university to discuss the recommended support and create an individualized support plan. 9. Implement the agreed-upon support throughout the academic year, as needed.

answer: During the application process at Nottingham Trent University (NTU), students who have declared a disability, learning difference, or support need will receive an email over the summer. If a student has not declared any support need at the application stage, they will not be sent any additional information.  To communicate disability, learning difference, or support needs to NTU, students should include relevant details in their application, such as an access statement or information about any required exam arrangements. They may also contact the Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU for further assistance.  The Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU offers support for a diverse range of needs, including dyslexia, autism, mental health conditions, chronic illnesses, and mobility impairments. They can provide advice on applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) to fund support, accessing academic support within NTU, implementing reasonable adjustments as recommended in evidence, and more.  Parents and carers of students with disabilities and learning differences play a vital role in preparing them for university life and supporting them throughout their studies. They can find more information on how to help their child prepare for university life and the support available on the NTU website.

answer: The Computer Science - Games Technology BSc (Hons) program is a full-time, undergraduate degree program offered at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) in the United Kingdom. The standard duration of the program is three years, but there is also an option for a four-year program with a foundation year for those who need additional preparation before starting the main degree. The program combines core computer science and software engineering skills with specialized games technology modules. Students have the opportunity to share ideas with other computer games students through the university's Computer Society, and the program shares a common first year with BSc (Hons) Computer Science and BSc (Hons) Software Engineering, allowing for flexibility in choosing a pathway after starting the program.

About Computer Science: From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science. You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive

of computer technology. The combination of a solid foundation in traditional computer science and games technology knowledge allows you to keep your options open regarding jobs and career paths. Our graduates are just as likely to move into well-paid careers with Investment banks or Motorsports
answer: The primary focus of the Computer Science - Games Technology (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) course at Clifton Campus is to provide students with a unique blend of traditional computer science and specialized games technology knowledge. This course equips students with a solid foundation in core computer science and software engineering skills in the first year, assuming no prior knowledge of computer programming. It then combines these foundational skills with specialized games technology modules, making it ideal for those interested in creative applications of computer technology.  The curriculum and modules of this course are designed to prepare students for diverse career opportunities in various industries. Students learn about topics such as robotics, networking and security, human-interactive systems, and game development. These skills are highly sought after in fields like investment banking, motorsports, and creative industries, ensuring that graduates have a wide range of career paths available to them. Additionally, students have access to resources like the university's robot arena, games consoles, and the Computer Society, which fosters collaboration and idea sharing with other computer games students across the country.

ground_truth: The primary focus of the Computer Science - Games Technology (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) course at Clifton Campus is to develop practical skills and knowledge in programming, maths, and engineering. The curriculum includes a solid foundation in traditional computer science combined with specialized games technology modules. This unique combination equips students for diverse career opportunities by allowing them to pursue creative applications of computer technology across various industries such as Investment banks, Motorsports companies, or AAA game studios.

Metadata: Car sharing at Nottingham Trent University

Text:

Electric vehicle (EV) charging: There are currently 10 EV charging bays at Clifton Campus where you can charge your electric vehicle. One of these is a dedicated accessible parking space for a blue-badge holder. All spaces are located in the Main Gate car park.
answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), there is one dedicated accessible parking space for a blue-badge holder for electric vehicles (EVs) in the Main Gate car park. However, the usage guidelines for EV chargers do not specifically distinguish between badge holders and non-holders.  To use the EV chargers, you need to download the app provided by the charging service provider, such as Mer, and create an account. There is a fee for using the chargers, which is currently 47p per kWh including VAT. It's essential to note that the parking fee is separate from the charging fee.  As for the specific rules regarding blue-badge holders, it would be best to check the university's official website or contact the university directly for the most accurate and up-to-date information.
contexts:
["Electric vehicle (EV) charging: There are currently 10 EV charging bays at Clifton Campus where you can charge your electric vehicle. One of these is a dedicated accessible parking space for a blue-badge holder. All spaces are located in the Main Gate car park.

To use the EV chargers. you need to first download the Mer Connect UK app from Google Play or the App Store and either register with Mer or charge your vehicle as a guest user. Follow the steps on the app and the charging station to begin. We recommend familiarising yourself with the instructions on Mer's website. For any issues, please contact Mer directly. If you use the EV chargers, they cost cost 47p per kW including VAT to use (subject to change). Users will still be required to pay their parking fee in addition to the charging fee â€“ the two are separate.

Text:"]
ground_truth: To use the EV chargers at Clifton Campus, all users need to download the Mer Connect UK app from Google Play or the App Store and register with Mer or charge as a guest user. The usage guidelines for both badge holders (blue-badge holders) and non-holders are not explicitly differentiated in the context provided. However, it is mentioned that there is one dedicated accessible parking space for blue-badge holders among the 10 EV charging bays located in the Main Gate car park. The cost to use the EV chargers is 47p per kW including VAT, and this fee is separate from the parking fee.

Overview", 'Overview				 

The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world, and the promotion of their mental wellbeing. The Interactive Systems Research Group  is led by Professor David Brown. This is a multi-disciplinary endeavour bringing together researchers and clinicians in virtual environments, serious games, games-based learning, assistive technologies, location-based services, mobile applications, robotics, health psychology and computational intelligence.

Areas of strength:

Serious games and virtual environments: Developing virtual environments and games for promoting cognitive and perceptual skills in people with intellectual disabilities, to change attitudes and behaviours in health and social related contexts, and for stroke rehabilitation. ground_truth: The focus of development within the Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG) related to serious games and virtual environments includes developing virtual environments and games for promoting cognitive and perceptual skills in people with intellectual disabilities, changing attitudes and behaviors in health and social contexts, and for stroke rehabilitation. Additionally, they assess the efficacy of serious games in educational and health contexts to address adoption barriers.

answer: Student Support Services play a crucial role in assisting parents, guardians, and carers with their student's transition into higher education at NTU. They offer various resources and guidance to help parents and carers better understand the university environment and support their student during this critical period. Some key aspects of Student Support Services include:  1. Providing information about the university, its facilities, and resources, helping parents and carers feel more comfortable with the transition. 2. Offering advice on how to best support their student during their time at university, including tips on study habits, time management, and navigating campus life. 3. Addressing common concerns that parents and carers may have, such as financial aid, housing, and academic support services. 4. Encouraging parents and carers to work closely with the university to resolve any issues that may arise, fostering a collaborative relationship between the university, the student, and their support network. 5. Offering resources specifically tailored to students with disabilities and learning differences, ensuring that these students receive the necessary accommodations and support to succeed in their studies. 6. Providing guidance on how to prepare for the transition to university, encouraging parents and carers to support their student in building resilience and independence. 7. Offering workshops and events for parents and carers, providing opportunities to connect with other families and learn more about the university experience.  In summary, Student Support Services at NTU aim to create a supportive and inclusive environment for all students, working closely with parents, guardians, and carers to ensure a smooth transition into higher education.

Additionally, they provide resources on their website specifically designed to help parents, guardians, and carers understand how they can encourage student development during their transition into higher education.

answer: Yes, Nottingham Trent University (NTU) is a great choice for students who are unsure about their Computing course selection. NTU allows changes between courses after the first term, providing students with the flexibility to find the right course that suits their interests and abilities. Throughout their studies, students receive support from dedicated academic advisors and tutors.  Regarding the incorporation of mathematics into Computer Science courses, NTU offers a variety of options to cater to different student preferences. For instance, the Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG) emphasizes a strong mathematical foundation in its curriculum, while other courses may focus more on practical application.  As for international students, NTU recognizes a wide range of qualifications for entry into its programs. Prospective students should consult the university's website or contact the International Office for specific details regarding their qualifications. It is essential to ensure that your qualifications meet the admission requirements before applying.

ground_truth: Nottingham Trent University (NTU) offers flexibility in course selection by allowing changes between courses after the first term. This can be beneficial for students who are unsure about their Computing course choice, as they have the opportunity to explore different options and find a suitable fit. NTU also provides support throughout studies, ensuring that students receive assistance when needed. In terms of mathematics in Computer Science courses, NTU caters to various student preferences by offering some maths in all courses while providing additional math-focused programs like BSc Computer Science (Games Technology) and BSc Data Science for those who wish to pursue a more mathematically intensive path. For international students, NTU has an admissions team that assists with qualification recognition from other countries.

answer: During the undergraduate level of study for Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) at Nottingham Trent University, students are equipped with various practical skills and knowledge that prepare them for further studies in BSc (Hons) Computer Science (Artificial Intelligence). Here's a summary of some key aspects:  1. Robust General Education in Computer Science: Students gain a strong foundation in computer science principles, with an emphasis on AI design and development. This includes topics such as programming, algorithms, data structures, and computer architecture.  2. AI Design and Development: Students learn about AI theories, methodologies, and techniques, including machine learning, neural networks, natural language processing, and computer vision. They also get hands-on experience in implementing these concepts through projects and assignments.  3. Data Analysis and Machine Learning: Students learn how to analyze large datasets, perform statistical analysis, and apply machine learning algorithms to solve real-world problems. This includes understanding concepts like regression, classification, clustering, and dimensionality reduction.  4. Ethical Considerations: Students explore the ethical implications of AI and big data, learning about issues such as privacy, bias, and accountability. This helps them develop a responsible and ethical approach to AI development.  5. Collaboration and Teamwork: Throughout the program, students work in teams on projects and assignments, fostering collaboration and teamwork skills that are essential in the professional world.  6. Research-Informed Teaching: The course incorporates current research findings in AI and computer science, ensuring that students are exposed to cutting-edge developments in the field.  7. Industry Connections: The program has strong connections with industry partners, providing students with opportunities for internships, work placements, and networking events. This helps students gain practical experience and build connections in the AI industry.  These skills and knowledge prepare students for further studies in BSc (Hons) Computer Science (Artificial Intelligence) by providing a strong foundation in AI theory and practice, as well as developing essential skills like problem-solving, critical thinking, and teamwork.

UK, there will be a shortage in the next ten years. This software engineering degree seeks to meet that need by producing graduates with the precise combination of skills required to design and develop robust, efficient, high-quality software.

Text:

The course leader and year 3 tutor for Computer Science BSc (Hons) is Dr. Andrew Pierson, who is a Principal Lecturer in Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.

The course leader for Software Engineering BSc (Hons) is Dr. Azi Meskaran, who is a Senior Lecturer in Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.

The course leader for Computing BSc (Hons) is Dr. Rob Ranson, who is a Principal Lecturer in Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.
answer: Our laboratories at Nottingham Trent University cater to several specialist areas within computer science, particularly in the field of software engineering. Here are some examples:  1. **Model-driven Development**: This technique emphasizes the creation of models to represent various aspects of a software system, such as its structure, behavior, and requirements. These models can then be automatically transformed into executable code.  2. **Data-driven Development**: This approach involves the heavy use of data in the software development process. It often includes techniques like machine learning and artificial intelligence to analyze and interpret large datasets.  3. **Robustness and Efficiency**: Our labs focus on developing software that is not only functional but also robust and efficient. This includes techniques for error handling, optimization, and performance tuning.  4. **Quality Assurance**: Quality assurance practices are crucial in software engineering to ensure that the final product meets the desired standards. This could involve unit testing, integration testing, and code reviews.  5. **Ethical Considerations**: As technology continues to evolve, so do the ethical implications of software development. Our labs provide opportunities to explore these issues and learn how to design software that respects privacy, promotes fairness, and avoids bias.

Additionally, the Security and Forensics Networking Laboratory features specialized networking and communications equipment from diverse providers, offering practical experience in various technologies. The Mobile and App Development Laboratory provides powerful PCs with software and emulators for app development and prototyping.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), you can learn game development skills with multiple languages such as Python, Java, and C# in the Computer Science - Games Technology (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) program. This program assumes no prior knowledge of computer programming and accepts students from a wide range of academic backgrounds. They provide all the necessary help and support to develop and succeed as a coder, starting with Python and moving rapidly to C++. During the second year, you will write code that integrates with networks and operating systems, and complete modules focused on game programming and 3D asset creation. Additionally, you will work as part of a team to develop a major project, often by applying game technology to the design of various projects.

Protecting organisations from cyber-attacks is a valuable skill and graduates are highly sought after and it’s one we’ll prepare you for. You’ll explore how to detect and identify security risks before building on this with developing your own preventative measures – all with plenty of

measures – all with plenty of opportunities to test your solutions in our industry-standard facilities. Building on a solid foundation covering network and system technologies, this course covers the core knowledge and skills needed to protect businesses against security threats. You will develop a

current security challenges but also anticipating future ones. We collaborate with academic institutions, industry partners, and government agencies to share knowledge and provide resources to drive innovation. Our goal is to provide our clients with the highest level of protection against cyber
answer: In the context of protecting organizations from cyber-attacks, developing preventative measures entails creating strategies and implementing technologies to safeguard digital assets and networks. This includes:  1. Implementing firewalls and intrusion detection systems to monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic. 2. Using encryption to secure sensitive data and communications. 3. Regularly updating and patching software to fix known vulnerabilities. 4. Establishing strong password policies and enforcing multi-factor authentication. 5. Conducting regular security audits and penetration testing to identify potential weaknesses. 6. Providing training and awareness programs for employees to educate them about common cybersecurity threats and best practices. 7. Developing incident response plans to quickly respond to and mitigate any security incidents that may occur. 8. Implementing access controls to limit who has access to sensitive data and systems. 9. Regularly backing up critical data to ensure its availability in case of a disaster or attack. 10. Collaborating with other organizations and sharing threat intelligence to stay informed about current and emerging cybersecurity threats.
contexts: ["Protecting organisations from cyber-attacks is a valuable skill and graduates are highly sought after and itâ€™s one weâ€™ll prepare you for. Building on a solid foundation covering network and system technologies, this course covers the core knowledge and skills needed to protect businesses against security threats. You will develop a detailed understanding of computer security issues, the detection of computer-based crime and the preservation and interpretation of digital evidence of crime. This course is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status. There's an opportunity for a year-long paid work placement and the School has strong links with local industry."]
ground_truth: Developing preventative measures in the context of protecting organizations from cyber-attacks involves exploring how to detect and identify security risks, followed by building on this knowledge to create strategies that can preemptively mitigate those threats. This process includes a detailed understanding of computer security issues, detection of computer-based crime, preservation, and interpretation of digital evidence, all within industry-standard facilities.

answer: The Cyber Security BSc (Hons) course aims to teach students how to develop preventative measures for security risks. This includes identifying security risks, understanding the basic principles and practice of collecting computer data as evidence of computer crime, learning about systems operation in terms of their software and hardware, and developing a detailed understanding of computer security issues. Students will also learn about the detection of computer-based crime and the preservation and interpretation of digital evidence of crime. This course is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT to Chartered IT Professional (CITP).

ground_truth: The Cyber Security BSc (Hons) course aims to enable students to identify security risks and develop preventative measures in technological solutions. It covers the basic principles and practice of collecting computer data as evidence of computer crime, understanding how systems operate in terms of their software and hardware infrastructure, managing such systems as system administrators specializing in ensuring security, and developing a good appreciation of security issues to protect organizations from breaches and crime.

answer: Graduates in cybersecurity are highly sought after by organizations due to several key skills they possess. These include:  1. Technical Expertise: A strong understanding of various cybersecurity concepts, tools, and technologies such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, encryption, and secure coding practices.  2. Problem-Solving Ability: The ability to analyze complex issues, identify vulnerabilities, and devise effective strategies to mitigate potential threats.  3. Critical Thinking: The capacity to evaluate situations logically, make informed decisions, and implement appropriate solutions.  4. Ethical Hacking: Knowledge of ethical hacking principles and techniques to proactively identify and fix security loopholes in systems.  5. Communication Skills: The ability to effectively communicate technical information to non-technical stakeholders, collaborate with teams, and liaise with external parties when necessary.  6. Continuous Learning: A commitment to staying updated on the latest developments in cybersecurity, including new threats, attack methods, and defensive strategies.  7. Adaptability: The flexibility to work in diverse environments, handle multiple tasks simultaneously, and respond quickly to changing circumstances.  8. Security Awareness: Understanding the importance of security best practices and promoting a culture of security within organizations.  9. Compliance Knowledge: Familiarity with relevant regulations, standards, and frameworks such as GDPR, ISO 27001, and NIST SP 800 series to ensure compliance with legal requirements.  10. Incident Response: Experience in managing and responding to security incidents, minimizing damage, and restoring normal operations as quickly as possible.

Additionally, there is an opportunity for year-long paid work placements with strong links to local industry.

Metadata: Data Science BSc (Hons)

Text:

The course leader for Cyber Security BSc (Hons) is Dr. Jon Robinson, who is a Principal Lecturer with the Department of Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.
answer: The Cyber Security BSc (Hons) degree at Nottingham Trent University imparts a range of foundational and advanced skills to prepare students for specializing as system administrators with a focus on ensuring security. These skills include:  1. Understanding of network and system technologies: Students learn about the basic principles and practice of networks, operating systems, and system architectures.  2. Knowledge of security risks and preventative measures: Students gain insights into various types of cyber threats, vulnerabilities, and attack vectors, as well as strategies to mitigate these risks.  3. Collection and analysis of computer data as evidence of computer crime: Students learn how to collect, analyze, and interpret digital evidence in the context of computer forensics.  4. System administration: Students acquire skills in managing and maintaining computer systems, including installing, configuring, and troubleshooting various software and hardware components.  5. Security management: Students learn about security policies, standards, and best practices, as well as how to implement and enforce these guidelines within an organization.  6. Ethical hacking and penetration testing: Students learn how to perform ethical hacking and penetration testing to identify vulnerabilities in computer systems and networks.  7. Incident response and disaster recovery: Students learn how to respond effectively to security incidents, including containment, eradication, and recovery activities.  8. Cryptography and secure communication: Students study the principles of cryptography, including symmetric and asymmetric encryption, digital signatures, and public key infrastructure (PKI).  9. Legal and regulatory aspects of cybersecurity: Students gain an understanding of relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards governing cybersecurity, such as GDPR, HIPAA, and PCI DSS.  10. Professional development: Students develop essential professional skills, such as communication, teamwork, problem-solving, and critical thinking, which are crucial for success in the cybersecurity field.

There's an opportunity for a year-long paid work placement and the School has strong links with local industry.", 'The Cyber Security BSc (Hons) course aims to enable you to identify security risks and preventative measures in technological solutions. You will learn the basic principles and practice of collecting computer data as evidence of computer crime and how systems operate in terms of their software and hardware infrastructure. Based on this you will learn how to manage such systems as a system administrator specialising in ensuring security. Your knowledge will be further developed to give you a good appreciation of security issues and the steps organisations need to take to protect themselves from security breaches and crime.



Metadata: Cyber Security (with foundation year) BSc (Hons)

Text:

Level(s) of Study: Undergraduate

Typical Offer: 72 UCAS tariff points

UCAS Code(s): I130 (full-time)

Start Date(s): Please ask a member of staff for the start date of this course, our staff here at the open day will be able to tell you that information.

Duration: Four years full-time']
ground_truth: The Cyber Security BSc (Hons) degree imparts foundational skills such as understanding basic principles and practice of collecting computer data as evidence of computer crime, along with knowledge about how systems operate in terms of their software and hardware infrastructure. It also provides advanced skills for managing these systems as a system administrator specializing in ensuring security. This includes developing a detailed understanding of computer security issues, detection of computer-based crimes, preservation and interpretation of digital evidence, and the steps organizations need to take to protect themselves from security breaches and crime.

answer: New students receive several important pieces of information over the summer regarding starting at NTtingham Trent University (NTU). These include details about accommodation, enrollment procedures, course schedules, and academic support services. One crucial piece of information is the reading of NTU emails, as a lot of essential information is communicated to students via their personal email accounts.  Having the My NTU app on their phone can help students stay updated by keeping track of communications and appointments. After enrollment, all emails will be sent to the student's NTU email address, so having the app ensures that students don't miss any important updates or opportunities to meet the team. Additionally, the app provides easy access to various university resources, such as timetables, grades, and announcements.

This is to keep on top of communications and appointments as, after enrolment, all emails will be sent to the student's NTU email address."]
ground_truth: New students receive a lot of information over the summer regarding starting at NTU to their personal email accounts. This includes details about support services that may be missed if not read carefully, and opportunities to meet the team which might not be taken up due to lack of awareness. Having the My NTU app on their phone can help students stay updated by keeping them informed about communications and appointments since all emails will be sent to their NTU email address after enrolment.

and to prepare for life after university, by talking to NTU to resolve any issues in the first instance; therefore, we ask parents and carers to help prepare for transition to university by supporting this practice.

At NTU, we feel parents and carers have a very important role to play in supporting the journey into university. Many parents and carers want to know what they can do to support that transition, so we have provided this information to get you started. We want to work together to ensure the time

As a parent or carer of a prospective NTU student, how should I help them prepare for university life? Parents/carers of students with disabilities and learning differences play a vital role in preparing them for university life and supporting them throughout their studies. Support is very

Reading NTU emails: New students receive a lot of information over the summer regarding starting at NTU to their personal email accounts. As such, information regarding support can be missed and opportunities to meet the team may not be taken up.

As a parent or guardian of a prospective student, what type of things do we need to talk about before my young person arrives at NTU? It would be useful to talk through some of the big decisions they need to make, such as course choice and accommodation options. Encourage them to consider all the

OUR GRADUATE PROMISE: NTU is committed to ensuring all our students realise their ambitions. In addition to our sector-leading support and assessed work-like experience across every course, we offer all our graduates a paid internship if they are not in employment 12 months after graduation.

Careers and employability: speak to the team to get help with your career goals. NTU is one of the UK’s most employment-focused universities, offering extensive careers and employment support to our students and graduates. We are ranked in the top 10 for work experience (RateMyPlacement Awards

together to ensure the time before your student starts at NTU is useful, and encourages trying a range of getting ready activities to ensure a smooth transition. This information tells you about the role that you can play in supporting your student as they move into higher education. In Student

2. JOIN A WELCOME TALK: A member of our University Executive Team will welcome you to NTU, outline what the University has to offer, and explore why we’re one of the most popular universities in the UK.
answer: NTU provides several tools to support teenagers during their first year of university experience. Here are some examples:  1. Graduate Promise: NTU guarantees all its students a paid internship if they are not employed 12 months after graduation. This initiative helps students gain practical work experience and improve their employability.  2. Careers and Employability Services: NTU offers extensive careers and employment support to students and graduates. They provide resources, workshops, and events to help students achieve their career goals.  3. Disability and Dyslexia Support Service: For students with disabilities and learning differences, NTU offers various support services, including academic adjustments, assistive technology, and mentoring programs.  4. Student Union: The NTU Student Union offers a wide range of clubs, societies, and events for students to get involved in. These activities help students build connections, develop skills, and create memorable experiences.  5. Transition Programs: NTU offers transition programs specifically designed for new students. These programs aim to help students adjust to university life, learn essential study skills, and connect with other students and staff members.  6. Peer Mentoring Scheme: NTU has a peer mentoring scheme where senior students act as mentors to new students. This program helps new students settle into university life, navigate the campus, and find answers to common questions.  7. Online Resources: NTU provides online resources, such as study guides, tutorial videos, and digital libraries, to help students succeed academically.  8. Counselling and Wellbeing Services: NTU offers counselling and wellbeing services to help students manage stress, anxiety, and other mental health concerns. These services provide confidential support and resources to help students maintain their emotional wellbeing.
contexts: ["Reading NTU emails: New students receive a lot of information over the summer regarding starting at NTU to their personal email accounts. As such, information regarding support can be missed and opportunities to meet the team may not be taken up.\n\nOnce they are enrolled, it is useful for students to have the My NTU app on their phone. This is to keep on top of communications and appointments as, after enrolment, all emails will be sent to the student's NTU email address."]
ground_truth: NTU provides various tools such as the My NTU app on students' phones, which helps them keep track of communications and appointments by sending all emails to their NTU email address. This support is particularly useful for new students in managing their first-year college experience.

Robin Hood renowned for his skills as an archer and swordsman. Originally depicted as a member of the yeoman class and traditionally dressed in Lincoln green, he is famous for stealing from the rich to give to the poor. Robin Hood's story evolved over centuries, becoming a popular folk figure

a popular folk figure during the Late Middle Ages. The historical existence of Robin Hood is debated, with some historians suggesting the name was a common alias for bandits.

7 foot effigy of Nottingham's legendary outlaw proudly stands on a 2.5 ton block of white Clipsham stone. In typical outlaw style, the statue of Robin Hood stands outside of Nottingham Castle, the point of his arrow is aimed at the gatehouse and the establishment within.

This chatbot, the ROBIN project, takes inspiration from the above story to provide an interactive experience with one of many heroes from English folklore. You can ask ROBIN questions about Nottingham Trent University’s Department of Computer Science.

If you are visiting the city after this open day at Nottingham Trent University, make sure to visit the famous statue of Robin Hood outside the castle grounds. Cast in eight pieces of half-inch thick bronze (made to last 6,000 years) and weighing half a ton, the 7 foot effigy of Nottingham's
answer: The legendary figure of Robin Hood is known for several key characteristics. He is traditionally depicted as a member of the yeoman class, dressed in Lincoln green, and skilled in archery and swordsmanship. Robin Hood is famous for stealing from the rich to give to the poor. His story has evolved over centuries, becoming a popular folk figure during the Late Middle Ages. However, the historical existence of Robin Hood is debated, with some historians suggesting the name was a common alias for bandits.  The 7-foot effigy of Robin Hood stands outside Nottingham Castle, aiming his arrow at the gatehouse. This statue is made of bronze and weighs half a ton. The statue takes inspiration from the Robin Hood legend, providing an interactive experience for visitors to learn about Nottingham Trent University's Department of Computer Science. If you are visiting the city after the open day, make sure to visit the famous statue of Robin Hood outside the castle grounds.
contexts: ["Robin Hood renowned for his skills as an archer and swordsman. The historical existence of Robin Hood is debated, with some historians suggesting the name was a common alias for bandits.\n\nIf you are visiting the city after this open day at Nottingham Trent University, make sure to visit the famous statue of Robin Hood outside the castle grounds. Cast in eight pieces of half-inch thick bronze (made to last 6,000 years) and weighing half a ton, the 7 foot effigy of Nottingham's legendary outlaw proudly stands on a 2.5 ton block of white Clipsham stone. In typical outlaw style, the statue of Robin Hood stands outside of Nottingham Castle, the point of his arrow is aimed at the gatehouse and the establishment within."]
ground_truth: Robin Hood is renowned for his skills as an archer and swordsman, originally depicted as a member of the yeoman class. He is famous for stealing from the rich to give to the poor. The story of Robin Hood evolved over centuries, becoming a popular folk figure during the Late Middle Ages. While the historical existence of Robin Hood is debated, with some historians suggesting it was an alias used by bandits, his legend has had significant cultural impact and remains a symbol of justice and rebellion against oppression.

Robin Hood is synonymous with Sherwood Forest, which is North of Clifton Campus and past the city centre to Mansfield, which is not too far from our Brackenhurst campus.

EXPLORE THE CITY: Nottingham city centre is only four miles from Clifton Campus and a five-minute walk from our City Campus. Why not take a student led tour of the city? Nottingham is a city in central England’s Midlands region. It’s known for its role in the Robin Hood legend and for the hilltop

Elizabethan mansion with gardens and a deer park. Robin Hood, from Nottingham, is the inspiration for my design as a chatbot!
answer: Robin Hood's bronze statue is located outside of Nottingham Castle, specifically outside the castle grounds.

answer: The Interdisciplinary Science and Technology Centre (ISTeC) offers modern laboratories equipped with the highest quality IT and Wi-Fi technology for teaching and research in biosciences, chemistry, computer science, and sports science. Some specific facilities include:  * Laboratories for biosciences, including those for cell culture, molecular biology, and genetics * Chemistry laboratories with equipment for organic, inorganic, analytical, and physical chemistry experiments * Computer science laboratories with workstations for programming, software development, and data analysis * Sports science laboratories with equipment for physiology testing, biomechanics analysis, and performance evaluation  In addition to these facilities, ISTeC also provides support for academic liaison, exam arrangements, and accessibility services to ensure a positive and inclusive learning environment for all students.

answer: Software Engineering contributes to improving efficiency in software development processes within the industry by providing students with the skills and knowledge to create high-quality software. This includes developing robust, efficient, and scalable software solutions, understanding software architecture and design principles, and applying best practices in software development methodologies such as Agile and DevOps. Additionally, software engineers are trained to write clean, maintainable code, which reduces the time and effort required for future updates and maintenance. Furthermore, software engineering programs often emphasize the importance of collaboration, communication, and teamwork, which are essential for efficient software development in a professional setting.

ground_truth: Software engineering contributes to improving efficiency in software development processes by providing graduates with a precise combination of skills required to design and develop robust, efficient, high-quality software. This approach meets the demand from industry and commerce for well-qualified software engineers who are confident, work-ready, and equipped with essential software skills.

answer: Studying in a full-time mode at Clifton Campus for the Data Science BSc (Hons) program offers several benefits:  1. Focused Learning: Full-time study allows you to dedicate all your time and energy to your studies, ensuring a focused and immersive learning experience.  2. Structured Schedule: A structured schedule helps maintain a balance between academic work, personal life, and other commitments. This can lead to better time management skills and improved productivity.  3. Immediate Feedback: In a full-time setting, you have immediate access to teachers and tutors, allowing for quick feedback on assignments and queries. This can help reinforce understanding and improve performance.  4. Campus Community: Being part of a university community provides opportunities for networking, collaboration, and social interactions. This can enrich your overall educational experience and contribute to personal growth.  5. Employability: Many employers prefer candidates with a full-time degree, as it demonstrates commitment, discipline, and a strong work ethic.  6. Access to Resources: As a full-time student, you have unrestricted access to university resources such as libraries, computer labs, and research facilities, which can enhance your learning experience and research capabilities.  7. Support Services: Universities often provide extensive support services for full-time students, including academic advising, career counseling, mental health resources, and financial aid assistance. These services can help ensure your success throughout your academic journey.

answer: In the foundation year of a full-time BSc (Hons) Cyber Security program at Clifton Campus, students will gain practical skills and knowledge in programming, mathematics, and engineering. These foundational subjects will prepare them for their second-year studies in Cyber Security, providing a strong basis for understanding the core knowledge and skills needed to protect businesses against security threats. Specifically, students will learn the basic principles and practice of collecting computer data as evidence of computer crime and how systems operate in terms of their software and hardware components. They will also have opportunities to test their solutions in industry-standard facilities. The course leader for Cyber Security BSc (Hons) is Dr. Jon Robinson, who is a Principal Lecturer with the Department of Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University.

Metadata: Dyslexia and other Specific Learning Difficulties (SpLDs)

Text: 

Nottingham Trent University is committed to providing a fully inclusive learning environment for all students.

Is support at university very different to that provided at school? Be prepared for a change in the way support is delivered and arranged. At school, you may have had regular contact with a Special Educational Needs Coordinator (SENCO) and have played an active role in deciding what support was

in deciding what support was required. At University, decisions about the support required are made by the student, together with a Disability Officer. However, we welcome any thoughts you might want to share or any suggestions of what has proved helpful in the past. Any technology, mentoring, BSL

The Disability Support Service offers advice and information for individual current and prospective disabled students on the types of support available. We have a dedicated disability officer for each school. They will be your main point of contact in the disability team and can support you to

for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs), access statements and exam arrangements, accessibility, information on the support available.
answer: The SpLD Support Team at Nottingham Trent University offers various forms of one-on-one support to students with specific learning difficulties (SpLDs) such as Dyslexia, Dyspraxia, and Dyscalculia. This support includes:  1. Assessment and diagnosis of SpLDs 2. Development of personalized study strategies and techniques 3. Provision of assistive technology, such as text-to-speech software, screen readers, and note-taking apps 4. Arranging for extended test time, alternative test formats, and other accommodations during exams 5. Offering mentoring and academic coaching to help students manage their workload and improve their organizational skills 6. Providing resources and materials in alternative formats, such as large print or audio recordings 7. Offering British Sign Language (BSL) interpreters for deaf students 8. Collaborating with students, Disability Officers, and lecturers to ensure that reasonable adjustments are made to support students' needs throughout their studies.

Metadata: Dyslexia and other Specific Learning Difficulties (SpLDs)

Text: 

Nottingham Trent University is committed to providing a fully inclusive learning environment for all students.
answer: The SpLD Support Team at Nottingham Trent University offers various forms of support to students with specific learning difficulties (SpLDs) in relation to access statements and exam arrangements. This includes:  1. Assistance in creating access statements, which outline any additional support required due to a student's SpLD. 2. Providing recommendations for reasonable adjustments, such as extended test time, use of a computer for written work, or alternative formats for course materials. 3. Collaborating with academic staff to ensure that appropriate accommodations are made during exams, such as extra time, a quiet room, or the use of a reader or scribe. 4. Offering one-to-one study skills support, including strategies for organization, time management, note-taking, and reading comprehension. 5. Providing resources and workshops on topics such as dyslexia awareness, self-advocacy, and stress management.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), there is support available for students with long-term diagnosed mental health conditions. The Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU offers a range of support including:  1. Advice on applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) to fund support. 2. DSA funded Specialist One to One Study Skills Support. 3. Information on how to access academic support within NTU, such as Library Study Support. 4. For more specific information, you may want to reach out to the dedicated Student Support Services team at NTU.

SUPPORT LIKE NO OTHER

To explore your individual support needs, talk to our dedicated Student Support Services team, who help all of our students to make the most out of their time with NTU.
answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), there are several in-person support options available for students with long-term diagnosed mental health conditions. These include:  1. Mental Health Mentoring and Access Team: They offer advice sessions throughout term-time to help students with long-term diagnosed mental health conditions apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs), create Access Statements, and arrange exam accommodations.  2. Disability and Inclusion Services: They provide support for a wide range of needs, including assistance with applying for DSAs, one-to-one study skills support, library study support, and implementing reasonable adjustments as recommended in evidence.  3. Support with Applying for DSAs: The university helps students apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) to fund their support needs.  4. DSA Funded Specialist One-to-One Study Skills Support: This service offers personalized support to help students develop effective study strategies and improve their academic performance.  5. Academic Support Within NTU: The university provides various academic support resources, such as library study support, to help students succeed in their studies.  6. Implementing Reasonable Adjustments: The university works with students to implement reasonable adjustments as recommended in their evidence, ensuring they have equal opportunities to participate in their courses.
