answer: Pursuing a full-time undergraduate degree in Computer Science with a focus on Artificial Intelligence at Clifton Campus offers several key features and benefits:  1. State-of-the-art Facilities: You'll study in cutting-edge facilities at the Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs.  2. Robust General Education: The course provides a robust general education in Computer Science, with an emphasis on AI design and development.  3. Emphasis on Practical Skills: The course puts theory into practice through skills development relevant to the modern world, particularly focusing on the use of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning, and cognitive computing.  4. Wide Range of Skills Development: The Computer Science (Artificial Intelligence) degree will provide the knowledge and skills necessary for a career in AI and big data.  5. Foundation Year Option: For students who need additional preparation, there's an option for a Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) course.  6. Career Opportunities: Graduates of this program are well-equipped to meet the challenges posed by AI and big data in the ever-changing job market.  7. Research-Informed Teaching: The course incorporates the latest research findings in AI and computer science, ensuring that students receive up-to-date and relevant education.  8. Building a Portfolio: The course allows students to develop their portfolio, showcasing their skills and projects in AI and computer science.  9. Broad Range of Skills Support: The Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) course supports students with a wide range of skills, making them versatile in the AI and computer science industries.  10. Inspiring and Motivating Environment: The course is designed to inspire and motivate students who are interested in AI technologies, preparing them to become leaders in the field.

ground_truth: Pursuing a full-time undergraduate degree in Computer Science with a focus on Artificial Intelligence at Clifton Campus offers several key features and benefits. Students will develop practical skills and knowledge in programming, maths, and engineering, which are essential for the field of AI. The course is designed to provide a strong foundation that enables students to excel in their second-year BSc (Hons) Computer Science program, specifically in Artificial Intelligence. Additionally, 100% of graduates from this program were found to be in highly skilled roles within 15 months post-graduation according to the Graduate Outcomes Survey for the academic year 2020/21.

Metadata: Travelling to Nottingham Trent University by car

Text:
answer: In NTU's car-sharing scheme for students, there is an option for fuel cost sharing. This means that if you are offering someone a lift, you can agree to split the fuel costs with the passenger. This helps to reduce daily travel costs and CO2 emissions for both parties involved. You can access your account online once you've registered, making it easy to find matches among NTU students or from the wider community.

["Text:

NTU operates a car-sharing scheme especially for students. It's designed to help you reduce your daily travel costs and CO2 emissions at the same time. It's totally free to use. It enables you to find others going your way, so you can share the journey. You can: take turns driving, offer someone a lift in exchange for a contribution to the fuel costs, look for someone to give you a lift. You can access your account online once you've registered. It makes searching as convenient as possible. You can choose to search for matches: among NTU students, or from the whole nationwide Liftshare database. You don't have to do it every day. It's completely flexible. Once you've found others going your way, you decide among yourselves how often it suits you to share.

ground_truth: The concept of fuel cost sharing in NTU's car-sharing scheme allows participants to take turns driving, offer someone a lift in exchange for their contribution to the fuel costs, or find others willing to give them a ride. This system enables students to share travel expenses and reduce individual CO2 emissions.

Metadata: Guide

Text:

SUPPORT LIKE NO OTHER
answer: To access and manage the NTU car-sharing scheme online, follow these steps:  1. Register: First, you need to register for the car-sharing scheme. You can do this by visiting the NTU car-sharing website and following the registration process.  2. Create an Account: After registration, create your account using your NTU email address and other required details.  3. Log In: Use your login credentials to log in to your account.  4. Search for Matches: Once logged in, you can search for matches based on your preferences, such as destination, departure time, and mode of contribution (driving, offering a lift, etc.).  5. Request/Offer a Ride: When you find a match, request or offer a ride accordingly.  6. Confirmation: The other party will confirm or decline your request/offer. If confirmed, you can communicate further to finalize the arrangements.  7. Drive Together: On the day of travel, meet your match and enjoy the shared journey.

ground_truth: To access and manage your account in the NTU car-sharing scheme, you need to register first. Once registered, you can log into your account online at any time to search for matches among other students or from the nationwide Liftshare database. You have complete flexibility on how often you choose to share rides with others.

Metadata: Car sharing at Nottingham Trent University

Text:
answer: Participating in the Ucycle student bike hire scheme at Nottingham Trent University offers several benefits:  1. Cost-effective: For just £49 a year, students can hire a bike and enjoy unlimited trips during that period. 2. Convenience: With over 200 bikes available, students can easily find a bike to suit their needs. 3. Security: Secure compounds for cycle parking are available at each campus, ensuring that students' bikes are safe when not in use. 4. Maintenance and support: Expert mechanics and advice are available at the City Campus-based workshop, ensuring that any issues with the bikes are promptly addressed. 5. Environmental impact: Cycling is a sustainable mode of transport, reducing carbon emissions and contributing to a greener campus environment. 6. Health and fitness: Regular cycling promotes physical activity, improving overall health and wellbeing. 7. Time-saving: Cycling can be faster than walking or waiting for public transportation, making it a convenient way to get around campus. 8. Community engagement: Participating in the bike hire scheme encourages a sense of community among students, promoting a more connected campus environment.

answer: A student receiving a sponsored cloud subscription as part of their Computing BSc (Hons) course would benefit in several ways:  1. Cost savings: Having a sponsored cloud subscription means that the student doesn't have to pay for the cloud services themselves, potentially saving a significant amount of money over the duration of their studies.  2. Access to cutting-edge technology: Cloud providers often offer the latest and most advanced technology, which can be crucial for gaining hands-on experience with modern tools and techniques.  3. Real-world project experience: By working with a sponsored cloud service, students can gain valuable experience in designing, deploying, and managing cloud-based projects, making them more attractive to potential employers upon graduation.  4. Flexibility and scalability: Cloud services allow students to easily scale their resources up or down depending on the needs of their projects, providing a more flexible environment for learning and experimentation.  5. Industry connections: Working with a sponsored cloud provider may also provide opportunities for networking and collaboration with professionals in the field, helping students build relationships that could lead to job opportunities or mentorship.
contexts: ["The Computing BSc (Hons) course is highly practical and provides a strong grounding in computing fundamentals. It gives you a comprehensive understanding of database systems, e-commerce, business information systems and Internet technologies. Practical skills developed will include involvement in multimedia and virtual reality projects. You'll cover the following networking and communications technology, business and information systems and interactive / multimedia development. If you take the Artificial Intelligence module in your final year you will participate in the Microsoft certified Azure AI Fundamentals program as part of your studies. The program is designed as a blended learning experience, combining instructor-led training with online materials accessed on the Microsoft Learn platform. Microsoft will sponsor your cloud subscription, course materials and certification test fees for no cost to you. You will also get the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals certificate when you"]
ground_truth: As part of their Computing BSc (Hons) course, students benefit from a sponsored cloud subscription by receiving Microsoft's support in covering the cost of their cloud subscription. Additionally, they gain access to online materials on the Microsoft Learn platform and are eligible for certification test fees waived at no cost.

answer: The final year BSc (Hons) Computing course curriculum at Nottingham Trent University consists of various components, including but not limited to:  1. Core modules such as Advanced Programming, Operating Systems, Database Systems, and Networks & Distributed Systems. 2. Specialist modules focusing on specific areas like Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Mining, and Cognitive Computing. 3. Project work, where students apply theoretical knowledge to real-world scenarios. 4. Professional development modules, helping students to develop essential skills for the workplace, such as teamwork, communication, and problem-solving. 5. Optional modules allowing students to tailor their studies according to their interests and career goals.  Enrolling in the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals program enhances students' learning experience by providing a blended learning experience that combines instructor-led training with online materials accessed on the platform. This program offers students the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with Microsoft's cloud-based AI tools and services, preparing them for working with real-world AI projects in the industry.

You'll cover the following networking and communications technology, business and information systems and interactive / multimedia development. If you take the Artificial Intelligence module in your final year you will participate in the Microsoft certified Azure AI Fundamentals program as part of your studies. The program is designed as a blended learning experience, combining instructor-led training with online materials accessed on the Microsoft Learn platform. Microsoft will sponsor your cloud subscription, course materials and certification test fees for no cost to you. You will also get the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals certificate when you"]
ground_truth: The final year BSc (Hons) Computing course curriculum includes networking and communications technology, business and information systems, interactive/multimedia development, and an Artificial Intelligence module. Enrolling in the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals program enhances students' learning experience by providing a blended learning approach with instructor-led training and online materials on the Microsoft Learn platform. Additionally, sponsored cloud subscription, course materials, and certification test fees contribute to an enriched educational environment.

answer: Participating in the Artificias AI module of the BSc (Hons) Computing course at Nottingham Trent University provides several opportunities for students.  1. Focus Areas: The Artificias AI module covers various topics such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, cognitive computing, data fusion, deep learning, and cooperative learning. These subjects are essential for understanding and working with emerging smart technologies.  2. Duration: The duration of the BSc (Hons) Computing course, including the Artificias AI module, is typically three years if you have the required qualifications to start directly on the degree program. However, there is also a four-year version with a foundation year for those without the necessary prerequisites.  3. Sponsorship: Nottingham Trent University has strong connections with various industries, and there may be opportunities for sponsorship or internships during the course. These experiences can help students gain practical experience and potentially secure employment upon graduation.  4. Certification: Upon successful completion of the course, students will receive a BSc (Hons) in Computing degree, which is accredited by BCS – the Chartered Institute for IT. This accreditation demonstrates that the course meets the standards required for the IT profession and can enhance students' employability.  5. Significance within the Computing Industry: The BSc (Hons) Computing course, particularly the Artificias AI module, equips students with the knowledge and skills necessary for careers in digital and technology occupations across a wide variety of different sectors in industrial, commercial, and scientific computing. The course is designed to meet the accreditation requirements of BCS – the Institute for IT, ensuring that students are prepared for the demands of the computing industry.

ground_truth: Participating in the Artificial Intelligence module of the BSc (Hons) Computing course provides opportunities such as sponsorship from Microsoft for cloud subscription, course materials, and certification test fees at no cost to students. Additionally, students will receive a Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals certificate upon completion. The course focuses on networking and communications technology, business and information systems, interactive/multimedia development, and includes practical skills in multimedia and virtual reality projects. It is designed as a blended learning experience with instructor-led training complemented by online materials from the Microsoft Learn platform. This module's significance within the computing industry lies in its comprehensive approach to AI education, preparing students for real-world applications of artificial intelligence technologies.

Text:
answer: Becoming an expert in data science at NTU involves several key components:  1. Big Data, Machine Learning, and Artificial Intelligence: NTU understands the transformative power of these technologies in various industries. The program equips students with the necessary skills and knowledge to excel in data science.  2. Accreditation: The course is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT, leading to Chartered Engineer (CEng) and IT Professional (CITP) status.  3. Work Experience: NTU is known for its strong emphasis on work experience. Students have the opportunity to undertake a year-long paid work placement, with previous students working with prestigious companies such as IBM.  4. Employment Focus: NTU is one of the UK’s most employment-focused universities, offering extensive careers and employment support to students and graduates.  5. Practical Experience: The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical experience, preparing students to actively engage in industrial, commercial, scientific, and technological research and development of intelligent systems.  6. Industry Relevance: The curriculum is designed to meet the demands of the industry and the government, addressing the shortages in the field of data science.  7. Skills Development: With a solid mathematical foundation, students will develop skills in data analysis, statistical modeling, machine learning, and more, making them highly sought after in the job market.  8. Research Opportunities: NTU offers opportunities for students to engage in research, fostering a vibrant community of like-minded individuals for collaborative learning and brainstorming sessions.  By pursuing data science at NTU, students can expect to gain a comprehensive understanding of data science, practical experience, and a strong foundation for a successful career in the field.
contexts: ["Unleash the Power of Data: Become an Expert in Data Science at NTU At NTU, we understand that big data, machine learning, and artificial intelligence are transforming industries. That's why our goal is to equip you with the skills and knowledge to become an expert in data science. Through our comprehensive program, you will develop a strong foundation in computer science, enabling you to extract valuable insights from data. Using a diverse set of statistical, algorithmic, and predictive tools, you will gain the ability to transform raw data into practical and actionable information, capable of predicting trends and driving outcomes. Are you ready to take on the challenges presented by big data and artificial intelligence? Our curriculum will empower you to develop data-driven solutions that optimize business processes, as well as harness the power of data to support human decision-making. But our approach goes beyond theory. You will have hands-on experience, applying your knowledge"]
ground_truth: The key components of becoming an expert in data science through NTU's program include developing a strong foundation in computer science, learning to extract valuable insights from data using statistical, algorithmic, and predictive tools. The benefits of this program are the ability to transform raw data into actionable information that can predict trends and drive outcomes, optimize business processes, and support human decision-making. Additionally, students gain hands-on experience applying their knowledge in real-world scenarios.

answer: The Human Interaction Technology Lab within the Computer Science (Games Technology) BSc (Hons) course at Clifton Campus serves as a specialist facility for the study, planning, and design of products and devices aimed at improving and supporting human interaction with computers. The lab includes state-of-the-art stereo projection equipment, among other technologies, which are essential for the research, development, and testing of innovative human-computer interfaces.
contexts:
["We focus on the Industrial and medical applications of game technologies; our student work can be groundbreaking and innovative and consistently attracts industry attention.

You will have access to superior facilities, equipment and software, including our Vicon Motion Capture Suite, our green screen and our VR-equipped Human Interaction Technology Lab.

The Computer Science (Games Technology) BSc (Hons) course shares a common first year with BSc (Hons) Computer Science and BSc (Hons) Software Engineering, allowing you the flexibility to review your pathway once you've started studying.

100% of our BSc (Hons) Computer Science (Games Technology) (SW) students were in work or further study 15 months after graduation (Graduate Outcomes Survey 2020/21)."]
ground_truth: The Human Interaction Technology Lab within the Computer Science (Games Technology) BSc (Hons) course at Clifton Campus is designed to provide students with access to advanced facilities and equipment, including VR-equipped technology. This lab likely plays a crucial role in allowing students to develop and test game technologies that involve human interaction, contributing to the innovative and groundbreayer work within the field of games technology.

answer: To be eligible for a Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA), you must meet all of the following criteria:  1. You must be under 65 years old when the academic year begins. 2. You must be a home student or an EU student who has been ordinarily resident in the UK, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man or Gibraltar for at least three years before the first day of the first academic year of your course. 3. You must be enrolled on a higher education course at a participating institution in the UK. 4. You must have a disability, long-term health condition, specific learning difficulty (SpLD), Autism Spectrum Condition (ASC), or mental health condition that affects your ability to study. 5. Your disability, long-term health condition, SpLD, ASC, or mental health condition must significantly impact your ability to study. 6. You must be able to demonstrate that you will incur additional costs or expenses due to your disability, long-term health condition, SpLD, ASC, or mental health condition while studying. 7. You must be able to show that you are studying a course that leads to a qualification at an appropriate level. 8. You must be able to show that you are studying on a full-time or part-time basis. 9. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that lasts at least one academic year. 10. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that leads to a qualification at an appropriate level. 11. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is eligible for funding. 12. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is not primarily designed for distance learning. 13. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is not primarily designed for work-based learning. 14. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is not primarily designed for part-time day release. 15. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is not primarily designed for sandwich courses. 16. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is not primarily designed for postgraduate research. 17. You must be able to show that you are studying on a course that is

The allowance is intended to cover extra costs or expenses that arise because of the student's disability while studying. It also includes recommendations for non-medical helper and assistive technology support at university.

answer: The Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA) is a financial support provided to students with disabilities, learning differences, or diagnosed additional support needs. Its purpose is to cover any extra costs or expenses that arise due to the student's disability during their studies. Eligible students can receive recommendations for non-medical helper and assistive technology support they might need at university. Both full-time and part-time undergraduate or postgraduate students can apply for DSA, although international students should contact the university directly to discuss alternatives.

Metadata: What is a disability?

Text: 

Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU supports students with a diverse range of support needs.

Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU supports students with a diverse range of support needs such as:
answer: There are several types of Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA) available for undergraduate and postgraduate students at Nottingham Trent University. These include:  1. Equipment Allowance: This covers the cost of specialist equipment, such as computers, software, and assistive technology, that you require due to your disability.  2. Non-Medical Helper Allowance: This covers the cost of support workers, such as note-takers, transcribers, or readers, who can help you with your studies.  3. Travel Allowance: If you have to travel further than other students to attend classes or access necessary facilities, you may be eligible for a travel allowance.  4. Specialist Study Skills Tutors: These tutors can provide one-to-one support to help you develop study skills, such as time management, note-taking, and essay writing.  5. Mentoring: Some students may benefit from mentoring support, which can help with personal development, goal setting, and academic progression.  6. British Sign Language (BSL) Interpreters: For students who are deaf or hard of hearing, BSL interpreters can be provided to facilitate communication during lectures and meetings.  7. Study Skills for Dyslexia and Other Specific Learning Difficulties: This support can help students with dyslexia or other specific learning difficulties to develop strategies for managing their studies effectively.  8. Additional Support: Depending on individual needs, additional support may be provided, such as extended library loans, alternative format materials, and exam arrangements.

DSA is available to full-time and part-time undergraduate or postgraduate students. International students should contact us directly do discuss alternatives to the DSA. DSA doesn't depend on household income\xa0â€“ what you can get depends on your own needs. You don't have to pay these back."]
ground_truth: Disabled Students' Allowances (DSA) available for undergraduate and postgraduate students include covering extra costs or expenses that arise due to disability while studying, as well as recommending non-medical helper and assistive technology support. DSA is not dependent on household income and does not need to be paid back.

answer: Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA) assists disabled students with their educational expenses by covering any extra costs or expenses that arise due to their disability while studying. This includes the cost of specialist equipment, such as computers, software, and assistive technology, as well as the cost of non-medical helper support, such as note-takers, scribes, or mentors. DSA is available to both full-time and part-time undergraduate or postgraduate students. International students should contact the university directly to discuss alternatives to DSA.

It also recommends non-medical helper and assistive technology support at university, available to both full-time and part-time undergraduate or postgraduate students.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng)
answer: The Software Engineering BSc (Hons) program offers several benefits due to its BCS accreditation. Firstly, it provides independent recognition that the course content is relevant to the IT profession. Secondly, it ensures a level of standardization across higher education institutions so that the courses meet the needs of employers. A key part of the accreditation is the incorporation of professional, ethical, social, and legal issues relating to computing. Lastly, graduating from a BCS accredited degree allows students to apply for professional membership of the BCS, giving them access to a wide range of resources and networking opportunities in the IT industry. Additionally, the program offers an opportunity for a year-long paid work placement with prestigious companies such as GE Consumer Finance and IBM.
contexts: ["Why choose Software Engineering BSc (Hons)? It is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT to Chartered Engineer (CEng) and IT Professional (CITP) status. There's an opportunity for a year-long paid work placement with prestigious companies such as GE Consumer Finance and IBM. You will have access to contact and share ideas with other computer games students throughout the country through our own Computer Society. This course shares a common first year with BSc (Hons) Computer Science and BSc (Hons) Computer Science (Games Technology) allowing you the flexibility to review your pathway once you've started studying. You will have access to ultra-modern facilities, equipment and software. Our student work can be ground-breaking, and innovative and consistently attracts industry attention."]
ground_truth: The Software Engineering BSc (Hons) program offers professional recognition through its accreditation by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT, which allows students to achieve Chartered Engineer (CEng) and IT Professional (CITP) status. This can enhance career opportunities as it is recognized in the industry and signifies a high standard of education and professionalism.

Will students fall behind academically if they go on placement? It is very unlikely that students will fall behind if they go on a placement. Placements are only approved if they are directly related to the student's course of study. We expect our placement students to learn industry-relevant

answer: It is very unlikely that students will fall behind if they go on a placement. Placements are only approved if they are directly related to the student's course of study. We expect our placement students to learn industry-relevant skills during their placement year, which can enhance their academic progress upon returning to university. Throughout the placement year, there is a minimum of 3 contact points with students by a member of staff within the Department. This is to make sure that they can have someone to talk to if there are any issues and we can monitor placement progress. Placement students are invited to attend regular meetings with their academic supervisor to discuss their work and ensure they are making appropriate progress. Additionally, students can still complete their coursework while on placement, and many universities offer flexible deadlines for assignments during the placement year.
contexts: ["Will students fall behind academically if they go on placement? It is very unlikely that students will fall behind if they go on a placement. Placements are only approved if they are directly related to the student's course of study. We expect our placement students to learn industry-relevant technical and soft skills, some of which may be more advanced than what they would encounter at university. We also provide students with the opportunity to achieve a Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice. This is a piece of coursework due in after the placement (but before final year) and consists of a work log, a report on their professional development, and a presentation. The Diploma allows students to practice their academic writing and presenting skills before they start their final year. The coursework they will have in final year will contain quite a lot of academic writing, so it is a good opportunity for them to get back into university-style work."]
ground_truth: If students participate in an academic placement that is directly related to their course of study, it is very unlikely that they will fall behind academically. In fact, the experience can enhance their learning by providing industry-relevant technical and soft skills, as well as opportunities for professional development through a Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice. This diploma includes work log, report on professional development, and presentation, which helps students practice academic writing and presenting skills before final year exams.

answer: It is very unlikely that students will fall behind if they go on a placement related to their course of study. Placements are only approved if they are directly related to the student's course of study. The university expects its placement students to learn industry-relevant skills during their placement, which can contribute positively to their academic progress.  Throughout the placement year, there is a minimum of 3 contact points with students by a member of staff within the Department. This is to ensure that students can have someone to talk to if there are any issues and the university can monitor placement progress. Placement students are invited to attend regular meetings with their academic supervisor to discuss their progress and any issues that may arise.  In addition, students who complete a placement year are often found to have a competitive edge in the job market due to the hands-on experience they gain during their placement. This can lead to better job opportunities upon graduation, which can ultimately benefit their academic progress in the long run.

ground_truth: If students participate in placements that are directly related to their course of study, it is very unlikely that they will fall behind academically. These placements aim to enhance industry-relevant technical and soft skills, which may be more advanced than university curriculum at the time. Additionally, students have the opportunity to work on a Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice, which includes coursework involving academic writing and presenting skills that prepare them for their final year of studies.

answer: The Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice provides several opportunities for students during their placement. These include:  1. Practicing academic writing and presenting skills before starting their final year. 2. Having a minimum of 3 contact points with a member of staff within the Department to discuss any issues and monitor placement progress. 3. Being invited to present about their professional development during the placement. 4. Completing a work log, a report on their professional development, and a presentation as part of the diploma coursework. 5. Gaining industry-relevant technical and soft skills that may be more advanced than what they would encounter at university. 6. Achieving a Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice, which can enhance their employability and competitiveness in the job market.

It also offers a chance to practice academic writing and presenting through a work log, report on professional development, and presentation due after the placement but before final year exams.

Do you accept qualifications from other countries? If you would like to discuss your qualifications that were achieved from a country outside of the United Kingdom, please refer to the admissions team who are here to help you at the Open Day. A member of staff will be able to help you find them.

study, general information about the university and Nottingham city itself, and much more. Why don’t you ask me a question and find out what knowledge I have?

Nottingham has a distinctive reputation as one of the UK’s top student destinations. Friendly, compact, and fantastically well-positioned, it’s a city that’s got it all – amazing experiences, life-changing opportunities, and a spirit all of it’s own.

Can students do their placments outside the UK? Can I do my placement abroad? Yes, if they can find a company to offer them the placement. Our employment team will support students with preparing their application for a placement either in the UK or abroad.

Do we have any students who have done their placements in other countries? Yes! Many NTU students have decided to do their placement abroad.
answer: Yes, students on an undergraduate full-time degree program at Nottingham Trent University can complete international placements abroad. Our employment team will support students with preparing their application for a placement either in the UK or abroad.  As for funding options, the Student Loans Company may provide a Tuition Fee Loan, and more information can be found on the UK Government website. However, for placements outside the UK, students might need to explore additional funding sources such as scholarships, grants, or financial aid offered by the host institution or organizations. It is recommended to discuss funding options with Nottingham Trent's "Student Money" Team or the relevant department for further guidance.

answer: Students typically intern during their third year of study, although a placement year may be taken between the second and third years as well. The internship provides students with real-world experience, helping them apply the theoretical knowledge they have gained during their studies. This practical experience can enhance their employability and give them a better understanding of the industry, which can in turn inform their final year project and dissertation. The internship can also provide valuable networking opportunities and potentially lead to job offers upon graduation.
contexts: ["Will students fall behind academically if they go on placement? It is very unlikely that students will fall behind if they go on a placement. Placements are only approved if they are directly related to the student's course of study. We expect our placement students to learn industry-relevant technical and soft skills, some of which may be more advanced than what they would encounter at university. We also provide students with the opportunity to achieve a Level 5 Diploma in Professional Practice. This is a piece of coursework due in after the placement (but before final year) and consists of a work log, a report on their professional development, and a presentation. The Diploma allows students to practice their academic writing and presenting skills before they start their final year. The coursework they will have in final year will contain quite a lot of academic writing, so it is a good opportunity for them to get back into university-style work."]
ground_truth: Students typically go on placement during their course of study rather than at a specific time like an internship would be scheduled. The context suggests that going on placement is unlikely to cause students to fall behind academically, as it is directly related to their studies and designed to enhance their skills. Placements are expected to provide industry-relevant technical and soft skills, which may even prepare them better for the academic writing and presenting required in final year studies.

What will I study on the Software Engineering BSc? You will learn core skills concerning the production of computer programs and applications, as well as specialist knowledge in areas such as software engineering and analysis and design. All of the courses within the Computer Science cluster share

You'll develop the practical skills and knowledge in programming, maths and engineering that will get you off to a flying start when you move onto BSc (Hons) Software Engineering in your second year. 92.9% of BSc Software Engineering graduates who entered employment are in a 'High Skilled' role 15

UK, there will be a shortage in the next ten years. This software engineering degree seeks to meet that need by producing graduates with the precise combination of skills required to design and develop robust, efficient, high-quality software.
answer: In a BSc (Hons) Software Engineering program, you would typically learn core skills concerning the production of computer programs and applications, including:  1. Programming: You will learn various programming languages such as Java, Python, C++, etc., and how to write clean, efficient, and maintainable code.  2. Software Engineering: This includes understanding the software development lifecycle (SDLC), software architecture, design patterns, and agile methodologies.  3. Analysis and Design: You will learn how to analyze user requirements, design software architectures, and create detailed design documents.  4. Databases: Understanding how to design, implement, and manage databases is crucial for software engineers. This includes SQL, NoSQL, and database management systems.  5. Algorithms and Data Structures: Knowledge of common algorithms and data structures is essential for solving complex problems efficiently.  6. Testing and Quality Assurance: Learning how to test software for bugs, performance issues, and security vulnerabilities is a key part of software engineering.  7. Version Control Systems: Familiarity with tools like Git and SVN is necessary for managing code changes and collaborating with other developers.  8. Software Maintenance: Understanding how to maintain, update, and improve existing software is an important aspect of software engineering.  9. Ethics and Professionalism: As a software engineer, you will learn about the ethical considerations involved in software development and the importance of professional conduct.  These skills and knowledge areas are shared across many computer science programs, but a BSc (Hons) Software Engineering program places a particular emphasis on these topics.

They could also participate in regular events hosted on campus by the local branch of the Institute of Mathematics and its Applications. Additionally, they may contribute to the academic activities of the mathematics department and have a role in exam arrangements, Accessibility, and Academic liaison. The Mathematics Society could help students network with other mathematics enthusiasts, gain practical experience, and potentially improve their employability prospects.

Text:

The inspiration for this chatbot (Real-time Open-day Bot for Information and Navigation, or ROBIN for short) comes from the heroic outlaw from English folklore, Robin Hood.

“Introduce yourself”: I am the Real-time Open-day Bot for Information and Navigation, but you can call me ROBIN for short. So, my name is ROBIN. I am an artificially intelligent chatbot and I am here to help you! I know all sorts of information about Nottingham, Nottingham Trent University, and the

The CIA Research Group has many active projects, including me, the ROBIN chatbot. Other projects include:

Trent University, and the Department of Computer Science here at Nottingham Trent University. Ask me any question and I will do my best to help you. If you want to know more about this chatbot, speak to Dr. Jordan Bird who can give you more information.
answer: The chatbot named ROBIN was created by a team consisting of Akash Shanthakumar, Dr. Jordan Bird, Dr. Farhad Fassihi-Tash, and Professor Ahmad Lotfi as part of a research paper called "Retrieval Augmented Large Language Model Chatbots in Higher Education: A Study on University Open Days". This research paper is part of a larger project called "HistoriChat: Learning from Historical Figures through AI Engagement", led by Dr. Jordan Bird, a Senior Lecturer from the Department of Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University (NTU).

This project is also known as the 'HistoriChat' project, with Dr. Jordan Bird serving as its principal investigator.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), the Department of Computer Science offers several undergraduate Computer Science courses. Here's some specific information about a few of them:  1. **Computer Science - MComp (Hons)**: This course is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT to Chartered Engineer (CEng) and IT Professional (CITP) status. Typical entry requirements are 112-120 UCAS tariff points, and the UCAS code is 350D (full-time) or G400 (sandwich).  2. **Computer Science - BSc (Hons)**: This course does not have a specific focus but covers a broad range of topics in Computer Science. Typical entry requirements are 112-120 UCAS tariff points, and the UCAS code is 350 (full-time).  3. **Computer Science (Games Technology) - BSc (Hons)**: This course focuses on the application of Computer Science principles to the creation of video games. Typical entry requirements are 112-120 UCAS tariff points, and the UCAS code is 351 (full-time).  4. **Computer Science (with foundation year) - BSc (Hons)**: This course is designed for students who don't meet the standard entry requirements. Typical entry requirements are 72 UCAS tariff points, and the UCAS code is I101.  5. **Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence (with foundation year) BSc (Hons)**: This course focuses on the principles and applications of Artificial Intelligence. Typical entry requirements are 72 UCAS tariff points, and the UCAS code is I400 (full-time).  In addition to these courses, NTU's Department of Computer Science also offers a Computing (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) course with a typical entry requirement of 72 UCAS tariff points and UCAS code I101.  Each course has a unique curriculum tailored to its focus area, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of Computer Science principles and preparing them for careers in the field. answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), they have specialized technology laboratories that cater to different areas within computer science. These labs provide students with state-of-the-art equipment to help them transform abstract concepts into practical applications. For instance, the Virtual Reality Lab allows students to create immersive educational experiences, while the Gaming Laboratory enables them to develop captivating gaming experiences.  Moreover, the curriculum at NTU emphasizes data-driven solutions that optimize business processes. Students learn to work with large amounts of data and develop the skills necessary to analyze, interpret, and make predictions based on this data. This focus on data analysis and interpretation equips students with the tools they need to better understand and communicate complex information related to various college subjects.  Additionally, the Interactive Systems Research Group at NTU focuses on the development of new technologies for cognitive and physical rehabilitation, as well as promoting mental wellbeing. Their research includes developing model-driven, data-driven, and diffusion techniques for AI and machine learning, which can be applied to various fields, including education.  In summary, NTU-developed technology improves understanding of college subjects by providing students with access to cutting-edge equipment and a curriculum that emphasizes data-driven solutions, as well as ongoing research in interactive systems and AI.

Text:

The inspiration for this chatbot (Real-time Open-day Bot for Information and Navigation, or ROBIN for short) comes from the heroic outlaw from English folklore, Robin Hood.

Robin Hood is synonymous with Sherwood Forest, which is North of Clifton Campus and past the city centre to Mansfield, which is not too far from our Brackenhurst campus.

project further. If you are interested in a hologram of your own in your business, school, or museum, talk to Dr. Jordan Bird who will be able to work with you!

Can I get my own hologram in my business, school, or museum, etc.? Yes, absolutely, if you are interested in a hologram of your own in your business, school, or museum, talk to Dr. Jordan Bird who will be able to work with you! We are always looking for partners from outside of NTU to work with us.

Virtual reality laboratory: A green studio with virtual reality headsets, screens and access to graphical editing packages.
answer: Yes, it is possible to obtain a virtual representation or hologram of Robin Hood inspired by Sherwood Forest and English folklore for educational purposes. To collaborate with Dr. Jordan Bird to create this experience, you would need to discuss your requirements and potential partnership opportunities with him. As mentioned earlier, he is the principal investigator of the HistoriChat project and leads the Virtual Reality Laboratory at Nottingham Trent University. He can help you create a customized hologram or virtual reality experience tailored to your needs. You can reach out to him via email or arrange a meeting to discuss further details.

Text:

Level(s) of Study: Undergraduate

100% of our BSc (Hons) Computer Science (Games Technology) (SW) students were in work or further study 15 months after graduation (Graduate Outcomes Survey 2020/21).
answer: Some examples of diverse job roles that graduates from computer science programs can pursue include:  1. Data Scientist: Analyzing and interpreting complex data to help organizations make informed decisions. 2. Software Developer: Writing, testing, and maintaining software applications. 3. IT Manager: Overseeing the overall technology strategy and operations of an organization. 4. UX Designer: Creating user-friendly interfaces for websites and mobile apps. 5. Machine Learning Engineer: Developing and implementing machine learning models to solve complex problems. 6. Network Architect: Designing and managing computer networks for businesses and organizations. 7. Database Administrator: Managing and maintaining databases to ensure they are secure, reliable, and performant. 8. Cybersecurity Analyst: Protecting computer systems and networks from cyber threats. 9. Technical Writer: Creating technical documentation for software products and systems. 10. DevOps Engineer: Ensuring smooth deployment and maintenance of software applications in production environments.  These roles are just a few examples, and there are many other opportunities available to computer science graduates depending on their interests and skillsets.

As a parent or carer of a prospective NTU student, how should I help them prepare for university life? Parents/carers of students with disabilities and learning differences play a vital role in preparing them for university life and supporting them throughout their studies. Support is very
answer: Students with disabilities may have various physical mobility and access needs, including but not limited to:  1. Wheelchair accessibility: Universities should ensure that all buildings, lecture halls, and other facilities are wheelchair accessible, with ramps, lifts, and wide doors. 2. Adjustable furniture: Some students may require adjustable desks, chairs, or other furniture to accommodate their specific needs. 3. Assistive technology: Universities may provide assistive technology such as screen readers, voice recognition software, and ergonomic keyboards to help students with visual or motor impairments. 4. Accessible study spaces: Universities should offer accessible study spaces, such as quiet rooms, study pods, and group study areas that cater to students with disabilities. 5. Transportation assistance: For students who may have difficulty navigating the campus, universities may provide transportation assistance, such as shuttle buses or personal mobility devices. 6. Physical accommodations: Universities may need to make physical accommodations for students with certain disabilities, such as providing seating during long lectures or allowing for extended time on exams.  At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), they offer a range of support services for students with disabilities, including:  1. Disability and Inclusion Services: They provide support for students with disabilities and learning differences, offering advice on Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs), access statements, exam arrangements, and accessibility. 2. Accessibility: NTU aims to make its campus as accessible as possible, with ramps, lifts, and accessible toilets throughout the campus. 3. Assistive technology: NTU provides a range of assistive technology, including screen readers, voice recognition software, and ergonomic keyboards. 4. Personal tutors: Each student has a personal tutor who can work with them to identify any additional support they may need due to a disability. 5. Adapted accommodation: NTU offers adapted accommodation for students with disabilities, including accessible bedrooms and bathrooms. 6. Student mentors: NTU pairs students with disabilities with student mentors who can offer guidance and support during their studies.

answer: Students attending university may have various specific learning differences such as Dyslexia, Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Autism Spectrum Condition (ASC), and Dyscalculia, among others. Nottingham Trent University provides support for these conditions through its Disability and Inclusion Services. For instance, they offer extended deadlines for assignments, alternative formats for reading materials, and exam arrangements to accommodate students' needs. They also provide academic liaison to help students communicate effectively with their lecturers and tutors. Additionally, they offer workshops and resources to help students manage their time, organize their workload, and develop effective study strategies. It's essential for students to disclose their condition to the university and discuss their individual needs with the Disability and Inclusion Services team.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), several forms of support are available for students with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Here are some examples:  1. Advice sessions: If you have evidence of an ADHD diagnosis, or are on a waiting list for a diagnosis, please book an advice session with the Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU. These sessions provide information on applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) to fund your support, DSA-funded Specialist One-to-One Study Skills Support, and how to access academic support within NTU, such as Library Study Support.  2. Reasonable adjustments: The university can help implement reasonable adjustments as recommended in your evidence, such as extended deadlines, exam arrangements, and note-taking assistance.  3. Academic support: NTU offers various academic support services, including study skills workshops, peer mentoring schemes, and academic tutors.  4. Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs): DSAs can provide funding for additional support services, such as one-to-one study skills support, specialist equipment, and travel expenses.  5. Assistive technology: The university provides assistive technology resources, such as text-to-speech software, screen readers, and digital recorders, to help students with ADHD manage their workload more effectively.  6. Exam accommodations: Accommodations such as extra time, a quiet room, or the use of a computer may be available during exams.  7. Peer mentoring schemes: These programs connect students with ADHD with peers who have successfully navigated university life with similar challenges.  8. Counseling and mental health support: The university offers counseling and mental health services to help students manage stress, anxiety, and other mental health concerns that may exacerbate symptoms of ADHD.

answer: Mathematics plays a crucial role in the field of computer science, especially for students interested in a degree with a heavy emphasis on math. Mathematics provides the foundational concepts and principles that underpin many aspects of computer science, including algorithms, data structures, and theoretical computer science. It helps students understand complex computational problems, design efficient solutions, and analyze the performance of these solutions.  In terms of a degree with a heavy emphasis on math, NTU offers a Computer Science and Mathematics BSc (Hons) program. This course combines the building blocks of mathematics such as algebra, calculus, and statistics with complementary computing skills, ensuring students have a strong mathematical foundation. This foundation sets them apart in the competitive job market and enhances their ability to solve complex computational problems.  Regarding international students discussing their qualifications related to mathematics from other countries when applying to NTU's programs, they should ensure that their qualifications are equivalent to those obtained in the UK. They may need to provide evidence of their mathematical abilities, such as transcripts, certificates, or test scores. NTU accepts various international qualifications, and prospective students should consult the university's website or contact the admissions office for specific requirements and guidance.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), several computer science courses require a significant amount of mathematics. Here are a few examples:  1. Computer Science - MComp (Hons): This course has a strong emphasis on both theoretical and practical aspects of computer science, including advanced mathematics.  2. Computer Science - BSc (Hons): This degree program also includes a substantial amount of mathematics, focusing on topics such as linear algebra, calculus, and discrete mathematics.  3. Computer Science (Games Technology) - BSc (Hons): Although this course has a focus on game development, it still requires a good understanding of mathematics, particularly for areas like physics simulations and artificial intelligence.  International students with qualifications from other countries can discuss their eligibility for these programs by providing their academic transcripts and meeting the minimum entry requirements set by the university. It's essential to check the specific admission criteria for each course on the NTU website or contact the admissions office for further guidance. Additionally, students may need to demonstrate proficiency in English language skills if they are not native speakers.

answer: Accessibility solutions aim to improve several key areas in mainstream Information and Communication Technology (ICT) through assistive technologies and robotics. These include:  1. Improving the accessibility of solutions and related services, making them more usable for people with various disabilities. 2. Determining whether the latest access techniques and new interaction modalities will provide a more accessible, more exploitable, and deeply embeddable approach in mainstream ICT. 3. Addressing the shortages in the field of data science, as outlined by industry and the government, by providing skills that are in high demand. 4. Robotics and automation technologies, particularly in the area of assistive robotics, to help individuals with disabilities live independently. 5. Developing computer vision technologies, such as object recognition, facial recognition, and image analysis, to aid businesses and individuals in various tasks. 6. Implementing robust, efficient, and quality software to ensure that technology is reliable and effective. 7. Enhancing the mental wellbeing of users through interactive systems designed for cognitive and physical rehabilitation. 8. Assisting older adults in maintaining independent living by equipping homes with sensor networks and providing technological solutions for those suffering from mild cognitive impairment. 9. Developing intelligent multimodal systems to promote communicational skills, especially for individuals with profound and multiple learning disabilities.

Robotics: Investigating the role of engagement in using robots with students with profound and multiple learning disabilities, the use of assistive technologies in controlling robots and the development of intelligent multimodal systems to promote communicational skills

Location-based services: Investigating the role of location-based and games technologies for route learning and the development of accurate spatial mental models and maps to develop improved confidence and abilities in independent travel for people with a wide range of impairments

User-centred design and user experience: Designing interactive systems involving users in co-design, and delivering systems, which focus on User Experience goals']
ground_truth: Accessibility solutions aim to improve mainstream ICT by enhancing the exploitability, embeddables, and overall accessibility of these systems. Assistive technologies contribute to this by providing more accessible interfaces for users with disabilities, while robotics investigates engagement in using robots with students who have learning disabilities, assisting them through control technologies and developing intelligent multimodal communication systems.

answer: Incorporating user-centered design principles is crucial when developing interactive systems for individuals with a wide range of impairments because it ensures that the technology is tailored to meet the specific needs and abilities of the users. By involving users in the design process, developers can create solutions that are intuitive, easy to use, and effective for the intended audience. This approach helps to minimize barriers to access and maximize the potential benefits of the technology for those with disabilities. Additionally, user-centered design promotes inclusivity and fosters a sense of ownership among users, leading to increased satisfaction and engagement with the technology.

answer: Assistive technologies play a crucial role in improving accessibility for individuals with disabilities. These technologies aim to enhance the ability of people with disabilities to perform tasks that might otherwise be difficult or impossible. They can help compensate for sensory, physical, or cognitive limitations, thereby promoting independence and equal participation in various aspects of life, including education, employment, and social activities.  In the context of Nottingham Trent University, the Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG) focuses on developing new technologies for cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world, addressing the shortages in the field of data science. The group works on projects such as improving accessibility of solutions and related services, determining whether the latest access techniques and new interaction modalities will provide a more accessible, more exploitable, and deeply embeddable approach in mainstream ICT. Additionally, the Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA) at NTU conducts research in areas like robotics, speech processing, and computational intelligence applications, all of which have potential applications in creating assistive technologies.  Examples of assistive technologies include screen readers for visually impaired individuals, voice recognition software for those with motor disabilities, and closed captioning for people with hearing impairments. These technologies can greatly improve the overall experience and opportunities for individuals with disabilities, fostering a more inclusive environment.

They also enable the use of robots with students who have profound and multiple learning disabilities, control assistive devices through various interaction modalities, and promote communicational skills through intelligent multimodal systems.

answer: Some emerging trends in utilizing smart devices for educational purposes, particularly in tailoring learning experiences for students with cognitive impairments and autism, include:  1. Personalized Learning: Smart devices can analyze a student's learning style, pace, and preferences to create a customized learning plan. This can help students with cognitive impairments and autism to better focus and engage with the material.  2. Adaptive Content: Intelligent systems can adapt the content being delivered based on the student's performance and understanding. This can help students with cognitive impairments and autism to avoid frustration and maintain motivation.  3. Gamification: Using games to teach concepts can make learning more engaging and fun for students with autism. These games can be designed to cater to the specific needs of these students, such as reducing sensory overload and providing clear, concise instructions.  4. Assistive Technologies: Devices like speech-to-text software, text-to-speech software, and augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) systems can help students with cognitive impairments and autism to communicate more effectively.  5. Virtual Reality (VR): VR can provide immersive, interactive learning experiences that can help students with autism to better understand complex concepts. It can also help reduce anxiety and improve social skills.  6. Artificial Intelligence (AI): AI can be used to analyze a student's behavior and adjust the learning environment accordingly. For example, AI can identify patterns in a student's responses to questions and adjust the difficulty level of subsequent questions.  7. Mobile Apps: Mobile apps can provide a convenient, portable way for students with cognitive impairments and autism to access educational resources. These apps can be designed to cater to the specific needs of these students, such as providing visual cues and reducing distractions.  8. Data Analysis: By collecting and analyzing data on a student's performance, educators can gain insights into the student's strengths and weaknesses. This can help them to tailor the learning experience to the student's individual needs.  These trends aim to create a more inclusive and effective learning environment for students with cognitive impairments and autism. However, it's important to note that each student is unique, so a combination of these strategies may be necessary to best support each individual.

Advanced learning systems analyze the affective state of learners and adapt the presentation of learning materials non-linearly, enhancing engagement and effectiveness.

Metadata: Tips

Text:

5 STEPS to the open day experience: 

1. CHECK-IN: Use our campus map to help you navigate around the event or ask a member of staff or a Student Ambassador in for directions.

Please note that parking on Clifton Campus is extremely limited and restrictions are in place. Students living outside NG14 can apply for a permit, together with those with extenuating circumstances. There are a limited number of permits which are sold on a first come first served basis from the

Electric vehicle (EV) charging: There are currently 10 EV charging bays at Clifton Campus where you can charge your electric vehicle. One of these is a dedicated accessible parking space for a blue-badge holder. All spaces are located in the Main Gate car park.
answer: On Clifton Campus, there are accessible parking spaces available to blue badge holders. These spaces can be found on the Clifton Campus map. Blue badge holders can also apply for a permit to park on campus, though parking is extremely limited and subject to availability. Additionally, there is one dedicated accessible parking space for a blue-badge holder that includes an EV charging bay in the Main Gate car park. For further information regarding disabled students' allowances (DSAs), access statements, exam arrangements, and other accessibility resources, please visit the university's website or speak with a member of staff or a Student Ambassador during the open day event.
contexts:

These include: students who travel in from further than NG14, students who live in the greater Nottingham area, but who have a real need to bring their vehicle to campus, and students with extenuating circumstances.

If you use the EV chargers, they cost cost 47p per kW including VAT to use (subject to change). answer: Pursuing higher education offers several key benefits:  1. Specialization: Higher education provides an opportunity to specialize in a specific field of interest, allowing students to gain in-depth knowledge and expertise.  2. Career Advancement: A degree from a reputable institution can increase employability and potentially lead to better job opportunities and higher salaries.  3. Critical Thinking Skills: Higher education encourages students to think critically, solve complex problems, and develop strong analytical skills.  4. Networking Opportunities: Universities offer numerous networking events and opportunities, which can help students connect with professionals in their chosen field.  5. Personal Development: University life fosters independence, self-discipline, and time management skills, preparing students for life after graduation.  6. Research Opportunities: Higher education institutions often have extensive resources for research, giving students the chance to contribute to new discoveries and innovations.  7. Global Perspective: Studying abroad can expose students to diverse cultures and perspectives, broadening their worldview and enhancing their adaptability.  8. Lifelong Learning: Higher education instills a love for learning and encourages continuous personal growth throughout one's life.
contexts: ['at degree level and beyond.']
ground_truth: Pursuing higher education offers several key benefits, including enhanced career opportunities, increased earning potential, improved critical thinking skills, a broader knowledge base, and greater personal development. Higher education can also provide networking opportunities and the ability to contribute more effectively to society through specialized expertise.

answer: Parents and carers can support a student's transition into university life at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) in several ways:  1. Encourage independence: Help your child learn to manage their own time, finances, and responsibilities. This will help them develop essential life skills.  2. Discuss course choices: Talk with your child about their interests, strengths, and career goals to help them choose a suitable course.  3. Assist with accommodation: Help your child research and compare accommodation options, ensuring they find a safe and comfortable place to live.  4. Familiarize with university resources: Explore the university website together to learn about available resources, such as academic support services, student organizations, and career development opportunities.  5. Attend events: Participate in university open days, orientation programs, and other events to gain a better understanding of the university environment and meet key contacts.  6. Offer emotional support: Be there to listen, offer advice, and provide encouragement during challenging times.  7. Foster communication: Encourage your child to communicate openly with university staff if they encounter any difficulties or concerns.  8. Prepare for financial management: Teach your child budgeting skills and discuss financial aid options, scholarships, and part-time job opportunities.  9. Support adjustment: Understand that the transition to university life may be difficult, and be patient as your child adjusts to their new surroundings and responsibilities.  10. Stay involved: Keep in touch with your child regularly, but allow them to maintain their independence. Offer support when needed, but encourage them to solve problems independently whenever possible.

ground_truth: At NTU, parents and carers can support their student's transition into university life by engaging in various getting ready activities to ensure a smooth transition. They are encouraged to work together with Student Support Services to address common concerns about the move to higher education, adulthood, and independent living. Additionally, for students with additional support needs, parents and carers can seek out available help to assist their student's settlement and coping in university life.

answer: Student Support Services at NTU play a significant role in supporting parents and carers during a student's transition into higher education. They understand the common concerns that parents and carers may have as their student makes the transition to university, adulthood, and independent living. Their goal is to work together with parents and carers to ensure a smooth transition for the student.  To achieve this, Student Support Services offer guidance on how parents and carers can best support their student during this critical period. They encourage parents and carers to communicate with the university to resolve any issues in the first instance, thereby fostering a collaborative approach between the family and the institution.  Additionally, Student Support Services provide resources and information to help parents and carers prepare for the transition to university, including advice on how to support their student's independence and self-reliance. They emphasize the importance of parents and carers helping their student develop essential skills for university life, such as time management, organization, and problem-solving abilities.  In summary, Student Support Services at NTU aim to support parents and carers by providing guidance, resources, and collaboration opportunities to ensure a successful transition for their student into higher education.

answer: Caregivers can support disabled or differently-abled students' university preparation at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) in several ways:  1. Understand the support available: Familiarize yourself with the resources and services offered by NTU's Disability and Inclusion Services, such as academic support, library study support, and reasonable adjustments.  2. Encourage independence: Help your child learn self-advocacy skills, so they can communicate their needs effectively to university staff and peers.  3. Apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs): Assist your child in applying for DSAs to cover the costs of necessary support, such as specialist one-to-one study skills support.  4. Attend events and meetings: Participate in university open days, information sessions, and meetings with support staff to gain a better understanding of the resources available and how they can best support your child.  5. Collaborate with university staff: Work closely with university staff to create a comprehensive support plan tailored to your child's unique needs.  6. Foster resilience: Encourage your child to develop coping strategies and resilience to navigate any challenges they may encounter during their university journey.  7. Stay informed: Keep up-to-date with changes in policies, laws, and best practices regarding disability support in higher education to ensure your child receives the best possible support.  8. Offer emotional support: Provide emotional support and encouragement throughout the university application process and beyond, helping your child build confidence in their abilities and potential.

Many parents and carers want to know what they can do to support that transition, so we have provided this information to get you started. We want to work together to ensure the time before your student starts at NTU is useful, and encourages trying a range of getting ready activities to ensure a smooth transition. This information tells you about the role that you can play in supporting your student as they move into higher education. In Student Support Services, we understand the common concerns that parents and carers can have as their student makes the transition to university, adulthood and independent living. Our experience is that parents and carers of students with additional support needs often have worries about how their student will settle in and cope with the university life, so we have also included information about the help available for both general or', 'As a parent or carer of a prospective NTU student, how should I help them prepare for university life? Parents/carers of students with disabilities and learning differences play a vital role in preparing them for university life and supporting them throughout their studies. Support is very different at university than it is at school and college so it is important that you support them over the summer to make sure they are prepared for all aspects of university life and have spoken to the Disability & Inclusion team regarding any support they may need setting up.']
ground_truth: Caregivers can support disabled or differently-abled students in preparing for university life at NTU by ensuring they are prepared for all aspects of university life and have spoken to the Disability & Inclusion team regarding any necessary support setup. It is important that caregivers provide support over the summer, as it differs from school or college environments.

answer: A Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence BSc (Hons) degree covers various key areas and skills related to artificial intelligence. Here are some of the main topics:  1. Machine Learning: Students learn about different machine learning algorithms, such as supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning. They also gain hands-on experience in implementing these algorithms to solve real-world problems.  2. Natural Language Processing (NLP): This involves teaching computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language. Skills include sentiment analysis, text classification, and language generation.  3. Problem Solving and Cognitive Techniques: Students learn various problem-solving strategies and cognitive techniques used in AI, such as heuristic search, constraint satisfaction, and decision trees.  4. Data Fusion, Deep Learning, and Cooperative Learning: These techniques help AI systems to combine multiple sources of data, learn complex patterns, and collaborate effectively.  5. Speech Processing: This includes topics like source separation, human identification, speech recognition, and speaker identification.  6. Ethical Considerations: Students learn about the ethical implications of AI, including privacy concerns, bias, and accountability.  7. Robust Software Development: Students develop the skills to create efficient, quality software that can handle real-world problems and challenges.  8. Industry Relevance: The course emphasizes the application of AI technologies in various sectors, preparing students for careers in digital and technology industries.  9. Professional Development: The course equips students with the skills and knowledge necessary for successful careers in AI, including communication, teamwork, and leadership.

You will then develop the knowledge and skills needed to face new technological and ethical challenges associated to the emerging new intelligent systems, and to adapt them for the real-world problems at both local and global scales.', 'Professional accreditation for Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence BSc (Hons): Accreditation of courses by the BCS provides independent recognition that the course content is relevant to the IT profession. It ensures a level of standardisation across Higher Education institutions so that the courses meet the needs of employers. A key part of the accreditation is the incorporation of professional, ethical, social and legal issues relating to computing. Graduating from a BCS accredited degree allows students to apply for professional membership of the BCS, giving an accelerated route to Chartered status. Employers often look for accredited degrees, and accredited degrees are recognised internationally.']
ground_truth: A Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence BSc (Hons) degree covers several key areas and skills related to artificial intelligence. These include designing and implementing robust, efficient, quality software; developing knowledge and skills to address new technological and ethical challenges associated with emerging intelligent systems; adapting these systems for real-world problems at both local and global scales; incorporating professional, ethical, social, and legal issues relating to computing. Graduates can apply for professional membership of the BCS, which provides an accelerated route to Chartered status.
