Metadata: Travelling to Nottingham Trent University by bus

Text:

Nottingham has a distinctive reputation as one of the UK’s top student destinations. Friendly, compact, and fantastically well-positioned, it’s a city that’s got it all – amazing experiences, life-changing opportunities, and a spirit all of it’s own.

Source: Disability and inclusion services at Nottingham Trent University

Metadata: What is a disability?

Text: 

Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU supports students with a diverse range of support needs.
answer: The Nottingham Trent Students Union (NTSU) provides various services to assist students with finding accommodation. These include:  1. Accommodation Finding Service: NTSU offers an accommodation finding service that helps students find suitable housing options. They work closely with landlords and letting agencies to ensure a wide variety of properties are available. 2. Accommodation Advice: NTSU provides advice on finding accommodation, including tips on viewing properties, negotiating rental agreements, and understanding tenancy agreements. 3. Accommodation Inspections: NTSU carries out regular inspections of student accommodation to ensure they meet safety standards and are suitable for living. 4. Accommodation Support: NTSU offers support to students who may encounter issues with their accommodation, such as disputes with landlords or problems with housemates. 5. Accommodation Tours: As part of the University Open Day, NTSU offers campus tours that include a tour of the student accommodation options available. 6. Accommodation Guides: NTSU publishes guides for students looking for accommodation, providing information on the different types of accommodation available, average costs, and tips for finding the best deal. 7. Accommodation Events: NTSU organizes events throughout the year to help students connect with each other and find potential housemates, such as flatmate fairs and social events.

A landlord who is a Golden owner is someone who has not had any upheld complaint made against them for at least 4 years and therefore is a good measure of how reasonable the landlord is. Students can also get housing advice from Nottingham Trent Students Union. We recommend that students always view accomodation before deciding to rent.

Metadata: Travelling to Nottingham Trent University by bus

Text:

What are the options for accomodation? Many first year students opt to live in university halls, which are large, self-catering residences. This is a good way to meet other people and makes budgeting easier as utility bills are usually included. However, larger residences don’t suit everyone.

Nottingham has a distinctive reputation as one of the UK’s top student destinations. Friendly, compact, and fantastically well-positioned, it’s a city that’s got it all – amazing experiences, life-changing opportunities, and a spirit all of it’s own.

Why NTU students love Nottingham:
answer: The Nottingham Trent Students Union (NTSU) provides various services to assist students with finding accommodation. These include:  1. Accommodation Finder: An online service that allows students to search for accommodation based on their preferences such as location, price range, and room type. 2. Accommodation Tours: Organized tours of available accommodations, including university halls and private housing options. 3. Advice and Guidance: Providing advice and guidance on various aspects of accommodation, such as contracts, deposits, and tenancy agreements. 4. Accommodation Support: Offering support and assistance throughout the accommodation process, including help with disputes and complaints. 5. Accommodation Fairs: Hosting events where students can meet landlords, letting agents, and current students to discuss accommodation options.

Related staff

Group Leader: Professor David J Brown is the leader for the Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
answer: Seminars and workshops in the context of interactive learning are smaller sessions led by an academic, providing an opportunity for a group of students to debate and discuss learning topics in a more informal and interactive setting. They are designed to encourage active participation, critical thinking, and collaboration among students.  In contrast to traditional lectures, seminars and workshops typically involve fewer students, allowing for more individual attention and discussion. These sessions may focus on specific topics, case studies, or current research, and often require students to prepare beforehand by reading relevant materials.  While lectures aim to give a broad overview of a subject and provide a framework for structuring learning, seminars and workshops allow students to delve deeper into specific aspects of the topic, ask questions, and engage in discussions with fellow students and the instructor.

ground_truth: Seminars and workshops in the context of interactive learning are smaller sessions where a group gets together, led by an academic. They provide an opportunity to debate and discuss learning, designed to be interactive. Unlike traditional lectures, which are delivered by an academic in lecture theatres or classrooms with the purpose of giving a framework for structured learning, seminars and workshops focus on engagement and discussion among participants.

answer: Seminars and workshops are smaller sessions that are often led by an academic and provide an opportunity for a group of students to debate and discuss learning. Lectures are less interactive than seminars and workshops.

answer: In university courses, students are expected to conduct independent research as part of their studies. This includes preparing for lectures and seminars by reading course materials, working on exercises, and conducting independent study. The exact breakdown of contact hours (lectures, seminars, workshops) and independent study varies depending on the year of study, but generally decreases as students progress through their course. For example, in Year 1, lectures/seminars/workshops might account for 33% of the student's time and independent study for 67%. In Year 3, this might decrease to 18% for lectures/seminars/workshops and 82% for independent study. Additionally, students may be expected to complete group projects and coursework, which require independent research and problem-solving skills.

answer: University-level coursework at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) may include various types of assignments, such as:  1. Essays: Writing long, structured pieces of writing based on research and analysis of specific topics. 2. Group work: Collaborating with peers on projects, presentations, or reports. 3. Individual projects: Developing and executing a project independently, demonstrating understanding and application of course concepts. 4. Group or individual presentations: Delivering oral presentations on a particular topic or project, either individually or as part of a group. 5. Portfolios: Compiling a collection of work showcasing progress and achievements throughout a course or program. 6. Practical exams: Demonstrating technical skills and knowledge through hands-on activities or exercises. 7. Written exams: Taking written tests to assess understanding of course material. 8. Group or individual projects: Working on a significant piece of work over an extended period, often culminating in a final product or presentation. 9. Networking and communications technology, business and information systems, and interactive/multimedia development projects: Applying course concepts to real-world problems or creating innovative solutions.

3: GET TO KNOW YOUR COURSE: Attend a subject talk, get hands-on experience in a taster session, and visit your subject hub to chat with academics and current students.
answer: In an academic setting, lectures, seminars, and workshops serve different purposes. Lectures are typically large, formal presentations delivered by an academic, aimed at giving a broad overview of a topic and providing a framework for further study. They are usually held in lecture theaters or classrooms and can be intimidating for students who are not accustomed to this format.  On the other hand, seminars and workshops are smaller, interactive sessions where a group of students gather, often led by an academic, to debate and discuss specific topics in greater depth. These sessions offer opportunities for students to ask questions, share ideas, and engage in discussions. They are designed to be interactive and promote active learning.  Independent research is another essential aspect of higher education, where students are expected to conduct preparatory reading for most lectures and seminars, prepare coursework, and carry out independent study such as reading textbooks and lecture notes. Practical sessions and workshops may also be included, where students meet with their lecturers in small groups to discuss problems or work through challenging topics. The rest of their time is spent on independent study.  In summary, while lectures provide a broad overview of a topic, seminars and workshops facilitate deeper engagement and discussion, and independent research allows students to delve deeper into the subject matter on their own.

ground_truth: The purpose of lectures in an academic setting is to provide a framework for structuring learning around. Lecture theatres can be large and overwhelming, especially if students are accustomed to classroom settings. In contrast, seminars and workshops are smaller sessions that offer interactive opportunities for debate and discussion among groups led by academics.

answer: The lack of metrics and standardized monitoring techniques on understanding plastic transport from land to sea has significant impacts. Without proper measurements, it is challenging to accurately estimate the amount of plastic waste that enters the ocean each year. This makes it difficult to track progress towards reducing plastic pollution and achieving sustainability goals. Additionally, without consistent methods for measuring plastic waste, it is hard to compare data between different regions, making it harder to identify hotspots of plastic pollution and prioritize efforts to address them.

ground_truth: The lack of metrics and standardized monitoring techniques makes it unclear how much plastic is transported every year from land to sea. This hinders a comprehensive understanding of the scale and impact of underwater plastic pollution.

CIFAKE - Classification and Explainable Identification of AI-Generated Synthetic Images

AI-generated images have rapidly improved recently, and the ability to detect them is becoming a critical necessity to ensure the authenticity and trustworthiness of image data. AI models have even beaten humans in art competitions!

to human and robotic forgers, suggesting that a system trained wholly on human forgeries can be easily attacked by robots to gain false-positive verification. The results after fine-tuning are effective, showing that such attacks can be prevented now, rather than after the first consumer

Signature Verification - Machine learning is often employed to detect real and forged signatures. However, robotic arms and generative models can overcome these systems and mount false-acceptance attacks. Our research results show that there are exclusive behaviours to human and robotic forgers,

answer: CIFAKE aids in authenticating image data against AI-generated fakes by developing and improving methods for classifying and explaining the identification of AI-generated synthetic images. This includes training models to recognize subtle differences between genuine and AI-generated images, and identifying exclusive behaviors of human and robotic forgers to prevent false-positive verifications. This helps ensure the authenticity and trustworthiness of image data in various applications.

The research on Quantum Intelligence in CIA focuses on exploring the new advancements of AI-Quantum hybrid methods that can lead to novel real-world intelligent systems in (but not limited to) smart living, cryptography, finance, and chemical structure design. The research has also extended to quantum-inspired algorithms where High-Power Computers (e.g., our Hydra Cluster facilities or cloud-based resources) are being used as simulation platforms for quantum intelligence.

ground_truth: CIFAKE aids in authenticating image data against AI-generated fakes by providing detection and explanation capabilities for artificial images produced by advanced AI models. This ensures the origin and integrity of visual content, which is crucial as these synthetic images become more realistic.

Text:

User-centred design and user experience: Designing interactive systems involving users in co-design, and delivering systems, which focus on User Experience goals
answer: The design method that improves mental well-being and thinking skills is "Digital Displays of Nature to Improve Mental Health". This design method uses biophilic design and smart environments to recognize the human instinct to connect with nature and the mental health benefits this can bring, such as reducing stress, anxiety, and depression, and improving cognitive function. This design method is part of the research conducted by the Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG) at Nottingham Trent University.

Using Games and affective state to reduce abnormal movements in home based rehabilitation for stroke patients: Our previous research has shown that adherence to exercise and accuracy of movement in unsupervised home rehabilitation settings are significant barriers to using co-designed games as

to using co-designed games as tools for the rehabilitation of the upper limb and hand following stroke when formal therapies stop. We propose a novel solution: first harnessing multimodal data to assess patient state of affect and using this information to adapt game mechanics to maintain

Serious games and virtual environments: Developing virtual environments and games for promoting cognitive and perceptual skills in people with intellectual disabilities, to change attitudes and behaviours in health and social related contexts, and for stroke rehabilitation. Assessing the efficacy

game mechanics to maintain engagement and optimise adherence to exercise; and second by providing in-game feedback to encourage increasingly accurate exercise over a period of time designed with patients and therapists
answer: Adapting game mechanics based on a stroke patient's affective state contributes to reducing the frequency and improving the duration of accurate movements during home-based rehabilitation exercises by maintaining engagement and optimizing adherence to exercise. By tailoring the game mechanics to match the patient's current emotional state, the system can create a more personalized experience that encourages the patient to continue exercising accurately for longer periods. This approach aims to overcome common barriers such as low motivation, lack of adherence, and difficulty maintaining accurate movements in unsupervised home rehabilitation settings.
contexts:
['Using Games and affective state to reduce abnormal movements in home based rehabilitation for stroke patients: Our previous research has shown that adherence to exercise and accuracy of movement in unsupervised home rehabilitation settings are significant barriers to using co-designed games as tools for the rehabilitation of the upper limb and hand following stroke when formal therapies stop. We propose a novel solution: first harnessing multimodal data to assess patient state of affect and using this information to adapt game mechanics to maintain engagement and optimise adherence to exercise; and second by providing in-game feedback to encourage increasingly accurate exercise over a period of time designed with patients and therapists

Further details on related research projects can be viewed on the ISRG website.

There are further details and downloads of other games and software developed by the group in the ISRG Software Repository.']
ground_truth: Adapting game mechanics based on a stroke patient's affective state contributes to reducing the frequency and improving the duration of accurate movements during home-based rehabilitation exercises by maintaining engagement through personalized experiences. By harnessing multimodal data to assess the patient's mood or emotional state, the game can dynamically adjust its difficulty level, feedback, and challenges in real-time. This approach ensures that patients remain motivated and focused on performing exercises accurately over extended periods, leading to better adherence to rehabilitation protocols and potentially enhancing recovery outcomes.

Metadata: Autism and AuDHD support at Nottingham Trent University

Text:

There is a range of support available for autistic students including: a school based Disability Officer, in-house and external one-to-one support, exam arrangements, social activities including a weekly lunch club, transition support for applicants.

Advice sessions - Our Disability Officers offer advice sessions for students who want to get their support set up or to discuss support and help at university. They can also help with matters such as: applying for Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs), orientation and accessing your course, getting
answer: An Access Statement is a document that outlines the specific adjustments and support measures required by a student with a disability, such as autism spectrum condition, to fully participate in their studies at Nottingham Trent University (NTU). It helps to ensure that the university provides appropriate accommodations to meet the individual needs of each student.  The Disability Officer at NTU can assist in arranging an Access Statement by working closely with the student to identify their specific needs and requirements. This may include discussing academic adjustments, such as extended deadlines, alternative assessments, or note-taking support; as well as non-academic support, such as providing information about support services, social activities, and transition support for applicants. The Disability Officer can also help with matters such as applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs), orientation, and accessing the course.
contexts:
['We have a Disability Officer dedicated to working with students with an autism spectrum condition. They will be your key point of contact while studying at NTU, and can support you to get an\xa0Access Statement in place â€“ as well as arranging your support needs.

They can also help with matters such as: applying for Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs), orientation and accessing your course, getting your access statement and exam arrangements in place academic liaison.

Specialist DSA funded one-to-one support - As a student with a disability, you may be eligible for a\xa0Disabled Students Allowance (DSA). DSAs are intended to cover any extra costs or expense that arise because of your disability while studying, as well as recommending any non-medical helper support you might need.']
ground_truth: The purpose of an Access Statement for students with an autism spectrum condition at NTU is to outline their specific support needs, which may include accommodations such as exam arrangements or specialized one-to-one support. The Disability Officer can assist in arranging it by acting as the key point of contact and helping the student get an Access Statement in place.

Text: 

Disability and Inclusion Services at NTU supports students with a diverse range of support needs.

There is a range of support available for autistic students including: a school based Disability Officer, in-house and external one-to-one support, exam arrangements, social activities including a weekly lunch club, transition support for applicants.

Specialist mentoring - Mentors work with our students on a one-to-one basis, addressing the barriers to learning created by autism spectrum conditions. Examples of these barriers include anxiety and stress, concentration difficulties, time management issues, and establishing an appropriate
answer: The Disability Officer plays a crucial role in supporting students with an autism spectrum condition at NTU. They offer a school-based service, working directly with students to address the barriers to learning created by autism spectrum conditions. These barriers may include anxiety and stress, concentration difficulties, time management issues, and establishing an appropriate study environment. Additionally, they may provide exam arrangements, social activities, transition support for applicants, and specialist mentoring to help students navigate their academic journey at NTU.

They can also help with matters such as: applying for Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs), orientation and accessing your course, getting your access statement and exam arrangements in place academic liaison.

Specialist DSA funded one-to-one support - As a student with a disability, you may be eligible for a\xa0Disabled Students Allowance (DSA). DSAs are intended to cover any extra costs or expense that arise because of your disability while studying, as well as recommending any non-medical helper support you might need.']
ground_truth: The Disability Officer plays a crucial role in supporting students with an autism spectrum condition at NTU by acting as their key point of contact. They assist these students in getting an Access Statement in place and arranging their support needs, including offering advice sessions for setting up support or discussing help at university, applying for Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs), orientation, accessing the course, academic liaison, and recommending non-medical helper support.

We have a Disability Officer dedicated to working with students with an autism spectrum condition. They will be your key point of contact while studying at NTU, and can support you to get an Access Statement in place – as well as arranging your support needs.

Staff can offer advice on: Applying for Disabled Students’ Allowances (DSAs) to fund your support, DSA funded Specialist One to One Study Skills Support, How to access academic support within NTU, e.g., Library Study Support, How to implement reasonable adjustments as recommended in your evidence
answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), the Disability Officer dedicated to working with students with an autism spectrum condition provides several forms of support. They serve as the key point of contact for these students while they are studying at NTU. Some specific ways they support autistic students include:  1. Assisting students in getting an Access Statement in place, which outlines any additional support or accommodations required due to their autism. 2. Arranging necessary support needs, such as reasonable adjustments as recommended in their evidence. 3. Offering advice on applying for Disabled Students’ Allowances (DSAs) to fund support, such as Specialist One-to-One Study Skills Support. 4. Providing guidance on accessing academic support within NTU, such as Library Study Support. 5. Offering assistance with implementing reasonable adjustments as recommended in their evidence.  In addition to supporting autistic students, the Disability Officer also offers advice sessions throughout term-time for students with long-term diagnosed mental health conditions. These services include help with applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs), creating access statements, and arranging exam arrangements.

Specialist DSA funded one-to-one support - As a student with a disability, you may be eligible for a\xa0Disabled Students Allowance (DSA). DSAs are intended to cover any extra costs or expense that arise because of your disability while studying, as well as recommending any non-medical helper support you might need.']
ground_truth: NTU's Disability Officer supports autistic students by acting as their key point of contact, helping them to get an Access Statement in place, arranging their support needs, offering advice sessions for setting up or discussing support at university, assisting with applying for Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs), and providing specialist DSA funded one-to-one support. They also help with orientation, accessing the course, academic liaison, and exam arrangements.

Working together to improve the University experience for students with Autism Spectrum Conditions (ASC) and for students who have both autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (AuDHD).We believe that autistic students should be respected and valued for their positive qualities as well

There is a range of support available for autistic students including: a school based Disability Officer, in-house and external one-to-one support, exam arrangements, social activities including a weekly lunch club, transition support for applicants.

Some students come to university having had these conditions their whole life, some have had a more recent diagnosis, and some come to university with no diagnosis. Every situation is unique.



Metadata: Autism and AuDHD support at Nottingham Trent University

Text:
answer: At Nottingham Trent University, students with autism spectrum conditions may face various challenges such as anxiety and stress, concentration difficulties, time management issues, and establishing an appropriate study environment. Specialist mentoring aims to address these barriers by providing one-on-one support tailored to each student's unique needs.  Mentors help students with autism develop independent learning skills by working closely with them to create personalized study plans, setting achievable goals, and offering guidance on effective study strategies. They also assist students in managing their time effectively, organizing their workload, and prioritizing tasks.  In terms of achieving a healthy work-life balance, mentors offer advice on self-care, stress management, and coping mechanisms. They also encourage students to participate in social activities, such as the weekly lunch club, to help build relationships and improve overall well-being.  Moreover, mentors collaborate with other support services at the university, such as the Disability Officer, to ensure that students with autism receive the necessary accommodations during exams and transitions. Transition support for applicants helps students prepare for university life and feel more comfortable adjusting to a new environment.  By providing ongoing support and fostering a supportive and inclusive learning environment, specialist mentors aim to help students with autism spectrum conditions thrive academically and personally at Nottingham Trent University.

answer: At universities, such as Nottingham Trent University, the approach to teaching and learning is often more independent compared to schools or colleges. While schools or colleges have a structured timetable and learning is closely monitored, universities encourage self-directed learning. This means that students are expected to manage their own study schedules, attend lectures, seminars, and workshops, and complete assignments and projects according to deadlines.  In addition, university teaching methods may include larger classes, lectures in lecture theaters, and smaller sessions known as seminars or workshops, where students get together to debate and discuss learning. These sessions are designed to be interactive. Furthermore, students are expected to conduct preparatory reading for most topics, which is known as independent research.  This shift towards more independent learning is aimed at developing students' skills in critical thinking, problem-solving, and self-motivation, which are essential for success in higher education and beyond.

answer: At university, teaching methods often involve a greater emphasis on independent learning compared to schools or colleges. While schools and colleges typically have a structured timetable and learning is closely monitored, universities encourage students to take responsibility for their own learning. This includes conducting preparatory reading, participating in seminars and workshops, and completing individual projects.  Seminars and workshops are smaller sessions led by an academic, providing opportunities for students to debate and discuss learning in a more interactive setting. Lectures, delivered by an academic and held in lecture theatres or classrooms, serve as a framework to structure learning around. However, university lecture theatres can be larger and potentially more intimidating for students who are accustomed to being taught in a classroom setting.  In summary, while schools and colleges may offer a more structured learning environment, universities place a greater emphasis on independent learning, encouraging students to take ownership of their education.

This transition to independent learning can be challenging for students as they adapt to new expectations.

answer: At school or college, teaching and learning is often more structured, with a set schedule and close monitoring of progress. Exams and assignments are usually predetermined, and there may be a greater emphasis on rote memorization. In contrast, university teaching and learning is more focused on independent study and critical thinking. Lectures are typically larger and less interactive than those in schools or colleges, while seminars and workshops are smaller and more discussion-based. At university, students are expected to conduct independent research and engage in self-directed learning. Additionally, universities place a greater emphasis on developing students' skills and preparing them for careers.

What are the main differences between school or college and university? Teaching and learning can feel different at university, and we are committed to supporting students through this transition. School or further education colleges have a structured timetable and learning is closely monitored,

the development of students.

in a classroom setting. Seminars and workshops – smaller sessions where a group gets together, led by an academic, providing an opportunity to debate and discuss learning. These are designed to be interactive. Independent research – students will be expected to conduct preparatory reading for most

Types of Learning: Lectures – delivered by an academic and held in lecture theatres or classrooms, the purpose of lectures is to give a framework to structure your learning around. Lecture theatres can be very large and overwhelming if a student is used to being taught in a classroom setting.

of the learning process and engagement of learners
answer: At school or college, teaching and learning are often more structured and closely monitored, with a focus on direct instruction and regular assessments. On the other hand, university teaching and learning are more focused on independent learning, with students expected to take responsibility for their own learning. This includes conducting preparatory reading, participating in seminars and workshops, and completing independent research. University learning is designed to be more interactive, with opportunities for debate and discussion in smaller groups led by academics. Additionally, university lectures may be held in larger lecture theatres, which can be overwhelming for students accustomed to classroom settings.

ground_truth: The main differences in teaching and learning approaches between school or college and university include structured timetables with closely monitored learning at schools or further education colleges, compared to higher education's focus on independent learning. Universities are committed to supporting students through this transition.

answer: First-year students at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) typically have several accommodation options available to them. Here are some of the most common ones:  1. University Halls: These are large, self-catering residences located near the university campuses. They offer a convenient way for students to meet others and manage their budgets since utility bills are usually included.  2. Private Rented Accommodation: Some students choose to rent a room in a shared house or even a flat on their own. This can be an expensive option, but it offers more independence.  3. Living at Home: Some students prefer to commute from their homes to the university. This can be a good option for those who want to ease into university life without having to adjust to independent living immediately.  4. Disabled Students' Accommodation: Disabled students are entitled to stay in halls of residence for the entirety of their degree course.  It's recommended that students view accommodations before making a decision. The Nottingham Trent Students Union recommends visiting unipol.org.uk, a website that advertises rental properties and allows tenants to rate the landlords. It's essential for students to consider all options carefully and choose what suits them best.
contexts: ['What are the options for accomodation? Many first year students opt to live in university halls, which are large, self-catering residences. This is a good way to meet other people and makes budgeting easier as utility bills are usually included. However, larger residences donâ€™t suit everyone. Alternatively, they might think about renting a room privately in a shared house. They might even rent a flat on their own â€“ although this can be quite an expensive option. Disabled students are entitled to stay in halls of residence for the duration of their degree course. However, this needs to be rebooked on a yearly basis. Studio flats are also available but are limited. Living at home can be a good option for some students, at least for the first year. This enables them to get used to university study without having to get used to independent living at the same time, and to retain regular family support during their transition to higher education.']
ground_truth: First year students have several accommodation options available in a university setting. They can live in university halls, which are large and self-catering residences that include utility bills; rent a room privately in a shared house; or rent a flat on their own, although this is often more expensive. Additionally, disabled students have the option to stay in halls of residence for the duration of their degree course with yearly rebooking requirements. Studio flats are also an available but limited option. Lastly, some students may choose to live at home during their first year to ease into university life while maintaining family support.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), there are several options for accommodation that include studio flats. These are typically more private and self-contained spaces, ideal for students who prefer a quieter environment. Here are some examples:  1. City Campus Student Village - Studio Flat: Located in the heart of Nottingham, this residence offers modern studio flats with en-suite bathrooms, kitchenettes, and Wi-Fi.  2. Clifton Student Village - Studio Flat: Situated near the Clifton Campus, this residence provides studio flats with en-suite bathrooms, kitchenettes, and communal social spaces.  3. Waverley Court - Studio Flat: Another option on the City Campus, Waverley Court offers studio flats with en-suite bathrooms, kitchenettes, and a common room.  4. Beacon Hill Studios: Located off-campus, these studio flats come with en-suite bathrooms, kitchenettes, and a shared laundry facility. They are a short bus ride away from the Clifton Campus.

OUR GRADUATE PROMISE: NTU is committed to ensuring all our students realise their ambitions. In addition to our sector-leading support and assessed work-like experience across every course, we offer all our graduates a paid internship if they are not in employment 12 months after graduation.

answer: NTU freshers can choose from several self-catering places. These include large, self-catering residences provided by the university, which are a popular choice for many first-year students due to the convenience of having utility bills included. Additionally, studio flats may also be available, although these are limited. Another option is living at home, which can be beneficial for some students, especially during the first year, as it allows them to adjust to university study without having to also get accustomed to a new living environment. It's recommended that students always view accommodations before making a decision to rent.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), the process for selecting a course that includes a placement option involves several steps:  1. Research: Explore the various courses offered by NTU, focusing on those that offer a placement year. You can find this information on the university's official website or by attending an open day event.  2. Subject Talks: Attend subject talks to gain a better understanding of the course content, structure, and the specific requirements for the placement year.  3. Taster Sessions: Participate in taster sessions to get hands-on experience with the course materials and gain insights into the practical aspects of the course.  4. Visit Subject Hub: Speak with academics and current students in your chosen subject area to gather firsthand experiences and insights about the course, including the placement year.  5. Exam Arrangements and Access Statement: If you have specific needs or requirements, such as disability-related accommodations, ensure that you discuss these with the relevant departments to arrange appropriate exam arrangements and access statements.  6. Academic Liaison: Establish communication channels with your academic advisors to stay updated on the course requirements, placement opportunities, and any necessary preparations for the placement year.  7. Placement Support: Utilize the services provided by NTU's Employability department to find suitable placement opportunities. They will source placements from various sources, check them for suitability, and maintain regular contact with students during their placement year.

answer: In your final year of the Software Engineering BSc program, if you choose to study the Artificial Intelligence module, you will gain experiences and knowledge in various aspects of AI. Here are some examples of what you might learn:  1. AI Algorithms: You will learn about different AI algorithms such as neural networks, decision trees, reinforcement learning, and genetic algorithms. You will understand their strengths, weaknesses, and applications.  2. Machine Learning: You will explore machine learning techniques, including supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning. You will learn how to train models, evaluate their performance, and apply them to solve real-world problems.  3. Deep Learning: You will delve into deep learning, a subset of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks with many layers. You will learn about convolutional neural networks (CNNs), recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks.  4. Natural Language Processing (NLP): You will study NLP techniques for understanding, generating, and manipulating human language. Topics may include sentiment analysis, named entity recognition, and machine translation.  5. Computer Vision: You will learn about computer vision techniques for analyzing and understanding visual data. Topics may include object detection, image segmentation, and facial recognition.  6. Robotics: You will explore the application of AI in robotics, including path planning, motion control, and manipulation.  7. Ethical Considerations: You will discuss the ethical implications of AI, including privacy, bias, and accountability.  8. Project Work: You will have the opportunity to work on a project applying AI to a real-world problem, gaining hands-on experience in designing, implementing, and evaluating AI solutions.

Additionally, these choices can help students stand out in the job market and increase their employability.

answer: Mathematicians and computer scientists play crucial roles in the digital revolution, particularly in creating a connected world. They contribute in several ways:  1. Developing Algorithms: Mathematicians create complex mathematical models and algorithms that form the backbone of many digital technologies. These algorithms help process, analyze, and interpret vast amounts of data, making it possible to create intelligent systems and machine learning models.  2. Designing Software: Computer scientists are responsible for designing and developing software that powers various digital devices and applications. They ensure that these systems are efficient, secure, and user-friendly, enabling seamless communication and interaction in a connected world.  3. Enhancing Data Analysis: Both mathematicians and computer scientists work on improving data analysis methods. They develop statistical models, machine learning algorithms, and data visualization tools to help organizations make informed decisions based on data.  4. Building Networks: Computer scientists are involved in designing and maintaining networks that connect devices worldwide. They work on network protocols, security measures, and optimization techniques to ensure fast, reliable, and secure data transmission.  5. Advancing AI and Machine Learning: As artificial intelligence and machine learning become increasingly important, both mathematicians and computer scientists are essential in developing these technologies. They create algorithms, train models, and test systems to improve AI's ability to learn, reason, and make decisions.  6. Collaborating Across Disciplines: Both mathematicians and computer scientists often collaborate with experts in other fields such as physics, engineering, and biology to solve complex problems and create innovative solutions. This collaboration helps drive advancements in areas like quantum computing, genetic algorithms, and neural networks.  In summary, mathematicians and computer scientists are key players in the digital revolution, working together to create a connected world by developing algorithms, software, enhancing data analysis, building networks, advancing AI, and collaborating across disciplines.

answer: The Computer Science Masters MComp (Hons) course covers both undergraduate and postgraduate content. It is designed to cover computer science foundation subjects and then build on this foundation with postgraduate level material in the final year. The course aims to equip students with the necessary knowledge and skills to develop robust, efficient, and quality software, and to face new technological and ethical challenges associated with emerging intelligent systems. The course covers topics such as data science, assistive technologies, computational intelligence, speech processing, and more. contexts: ['What youâ€™ll study on the Computer Science Masters MComp (Hons) course: This course combines undergraduate and postgraduate content and is designed to cover computer science foundation subjects and then build on this foundation with postgraduate level material in the final year. ground_truth: The Computer Science Masters MComp (Hons) course covers both undergraduate and postgraduate content, starting with computer science foundation subjects. In the final year, it builds on this foundation with advanced material in specialized areas such as artificial intelligence, cloud computing, advanced analysis and design, embedded systems, and programming. Additionally, students will engage in a group project for multidisciplinary engineering experience and an individual project to develop innovative software or hardware.

answer: Obtaining an internship upon graduation can be a valuable addition to your CV in several ways:  1. Gain Real-World Experience: An internship provides an opportunity to apply the theoretical knowledge gained during your academic studies in a practical setting. This hands-on experience can help you better understand the industry, its challenges, and opportunities.  2. Develop Professional Skills: Internships often involve working on projects, collaborating with teams, and interacting with professionals. These experiences can help you develop essential professional skills such as communication, teamwork, problem-solving, and time management.  3. Networking Opportunities: Internships offer chances to network with industry professionals who might become potential mentors, references, or future employers. Building these connections can be beneficial for your career growth.  4. Increase Employability: Completing an internship shows potential employers that you have initiative, are motivated, and have a genuine interest in the field. This can make you stand out among other job applicants.  5. Potential Job Offers: Some internships lead to full-time job offers, providing a smooth transition from education to employment. Even if a job offer isn't immediate, an impressive performance during an internship can increase the likelihood of being considered for future positions.  6. Enhance Your CV: Having an internship listed on your CV demonstrates your commitment to gaining practical experience and your willingness to go the extra mile to secure a position in your chosen field.
contexts: ['when you graduate â€“ a valuable addition to your CV.']
ground_truth: Obtaining an internship upon graduation can be considered a valuable addition to your CV in several ways. It demonstrates practical experience and the ability to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world settings, showcases initiative and commitment to professional development, provides networking opportunities with industry professionals, and may lead to potential job offers or references from reputable employers.

answer: Adding graduation to your CV brings several benefits after completing your education:  1. Credibility: A degree from a recognized university adds credibility to your qualifications, demonstrating that you have met the required standards of academic rigor.  2. Specialization: A degree in a specific field shows that you have gained in-depth knowledge and expertise in that area, making you a more attractive candidate to potential employers.  3. Skills Development: University education provides opportunities to develop a wide range of transferable skills such as critical thinking, problem-solving, communication, teamwork, and leadership. These skills are highly valued by employers across various industries.  4. Networking: Universities offer numerous opportunities to network with professionals, alumni, and fellow students, which can lead to job opportunities and valuable connections in your chosen field.  5. Employability: Many employers prefer candidates with a degree because it indicates a certain level of dedication, discipline, and commitment to learning. A degree can increase your chances of being hired and can potentially lead to better job prospects and higher salaries.  6. International Recognition: Accredited degrees are recognized internationally, making it easier for you to work abroad if you wish to do so.  7. Professional Development: Some degrees require or offer internships, work placements, or practical experience, which can give you a competitive edge when applying for jobs.  8. Personal Growth: University education offers opportunities for personal growth, allowing you to broaden your horizons, challenge yourself, and develop a lifelong love of learning.
contexts: ['when you graduate â€“ a valuable addition to your CV.']
ground_truth: Adding graduation to your CV brings several benefits, including showcasing the completion of formal education and training in a specific field, which can enhance employability. It also demonstrates commitment, achievement, and readiness for professional roles that require specialized knowledge or skills.

answer: Obtaining an MBA (Master of Business Administration) can offer several benefits as a valuable addition to one's CV after graduation:  1. Broad Business Knowledge: An MBA program provides a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of business, such as marketing, finance, operations, strategy, and leadership. This broad knowledge equips graduates with the necessary skills to excel in diverse business environments.  2. Networking Opportunities: MBA programs often attract students from various industries and countries, providing a rich network of contacts. These connections can prove beneficial throughout one's career, offering opportunities for collaboration, mentorship, and job prospects.  3. Career Advancement: Many employers view an MBA as evidence of a candidate's commitment to furthering their business acumen and potential for leadership roles. An MBA can help candidates transition into management positions or advance within their current organizations.  4. Specialization: Some MBA programs offer the opportunity to specialize in specific areas such as entrepreneurship, international business, technology management, or consulting. This focus can enhance one's expertise and make them more attractive to potential employers.  5. Increased Earning Potential: According to the Graduate Management Admission Council (GMAC), the average salary increase for MBA graduates is around 50%. This significant salary boost can lead to increased earning potential over the course of one's career.  6. Soft Skills Development: MBA programs emphasize the development of essential soft skills such as communication, teamwork, problem-solving, and critical thinking. These skills are highly valued by employers and can contribute to one's overall professional success.  7. Global Perspective: Many MBA programs offer international study opportunities or collaborations with foreign institutions. This exposure to diverse cultures and business practices can provide a valuable global perspective that is increasingly important in today's interconnected world.
contexts: ['when you graduate â€“ a valuable addition to your CV.']
ground_truth: Obtaining an MBA offers several benefits as a valuable addition to one's CV after graduation, including enhanced leadership skills, improved business acumen, expanded professional network, and increased employability in various industries. It also provides the opportunity for career advancement and higher earning potential.

SUPPORT LIKE NO OTHER

To explore your individual support needs, talk to our dedicated Student Support Services team, who help all of our students to make the most out of their time with NTU.
answer: The NTU Employability department provides several services to support student placements and career development. These include:  1. Online Placement Website: They have an online platform called InPlace, where students can find and apply for placements.  2. Sourcing Placements: Employability sources placements from various industries and companies, ensuring they are suitable for students' academic backgrounds and career aspirations.  3. Career Guidance: They offer career guidance to help students with job applications, resume building, interview preparation, and more.  4. Department Initiatives: The department also supports career development through various initiatives tailored to each department, such as workshops, networking events, and mentoring programs.  5. Internship Promise: NTU offers a paid internship to all its graduates if they are not employed 12 months after graduation.  6. Disability and Inclusion Services: For students with diverse support needs, there is a dedicated team to help ensure everyone has equal opportunities for success.
contexts: ['Will students get help with placements? Yes, students can get help with placements. There is a Department at NTU specifically for supporting student careers - called "Employability". They have an online website for finding placements called InPlace. Employability will source placements from business contacts and other job adverts, check through them to make sure it\'s suitable for our students, and upload them to InPlace. This means there is a single database where students can find a placement. There is also 1-to-1 support available from Employability to help students with job applications as well as Department initiatives to support career development. Students can also source their own placements but Employability and the Department will check the placement first to make sure it is the right kind of opportunity. ground_truth: The NTU Employability department provides several services to support student placements and career development, including sourcing placements from business contacts and job adverts, ensuring suitability for students before uploading them to the InPlace database. They offer 1-to-1 support for job applications and Department initiatives for career development. Additionally, they check externally sourced placements for appropriateness and maintain a minimum of three contact points with students throughout their placement year.

answer: At Nottingham Trent University (NTU), the Employability Department provides several types of support to students during their placement period. Here are some examples:  1. Online platform for finding placements: NTU has an online platform called InPlace, where students can find suitable placements based on their interests, qualifications, and career goals.  2. Sourcing placements: The Employability team sources placements from various organizations and industries, ensuring that they are relevant and beneficial for students.  3. Checking placements: Before students start their placements, the Employability team checks the opportunities to ensure they are appropriate and meet the necessary requirements.  4. Career guidance: The team offers advice on applying for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) to fund support, DSA-funded Specialist One-to-One Study Skills Support, and implementing reasonable adjustments as recommended in students' evidence from Employability.  5. Job application assistance: The team helps students with job applications, providing guidance on writing CVs, cover letters, and preparing for interviews.  6. Department initiatives for career development: NTU offers various department initiatives to support students' career development, such as workshops, networking events, and mentoring programs.  7. Internship guarantee: NTU is committed to helping students realize their ambitions. As part of its Graduate Promise, the university offers all graduates a paid internship if they are not in employment 12 months after graduation.
contexts: ['Will students get help with placements? Yes, students can get help with placements. There is a Department at NTU specifically for supporting student careers - called "Employability". They have an online website for finding placements called InPlace. Employability will source placements from business contacts and other job adverts, check through them to make sure it\'s suitable for our students, and upload them to InPlace. This means there is a single database where students can find a placement. There is also 1-to-1 support available from Employability to help students with job applications as well as Department initiatives to support career development. Students can also source their own placements but Employability and the Department will check the placement first to make sure it is the right kind of opportunity. Throughout the placement year, there is a minimum of 3 contact points with students by a member of staff within the Department. This is to make sure that they can have', 'that they can have someone to talk to if there are any issues and we can monitor placement progress. Placement students are invited back for a day before they re-join as a final year student. This is to help them network with other placement students so they know who their peers are since they will be joining an entirely different cohort in their final year. We also provide information to placement students on their final year projects and remind them of other relevant university information.']
ground_truth: During the placement period, NTU's Employability Department provides various forms of support to students including sourcing and vetting suitable job opportunities for them on InPlace, offering 1-to-1 support for job applications, ensuring a minimum of three contact points with staff throughout the year to address any issues and monitor progress, organizing networking events before final re-entry into their cohort, providing information about final year projects, and reminding students of other relevant university information.

answer: The Computer Science - Games Technology BSc (Hons) program at Nottingham Trent University is structured to provide a foundation of core computer science and software engineering skills in the first year, assuming no prior knowledge of computer programming. The program accepts students from a wide range of academic backgrounds and provides all the necessary help and support to develop and succeed as a coder.  Beginning with Python, students will learn essential programming concepts such as data structures, algorithms, and object-oriented programming. In the second year, students will delve deeper into game development topics, including 3D modeling, animation, and game engines. They will also gain experience working with Unity, a popular game development platform.  In the final year, students will focus on advanced topics such as artificial intelligence, network programming, and computer graphics. They will also work on a significant practical project, applying the skills they've learned to create a complete game or game-related application. Throughout the program, students will have opportunities to collaborate with peers, participate in workshops, and attend guest lectures from industry professionals.
contexts: ['Within Computer Science - Games Technology (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) we assume no prior knowledge of computer programming and accept students from a wide range of academic backgrounds. We will provide all the help and support you need to develop and succeed as a coder. Beginning with Python but moving rapidly to C++ will equip you with the technical skills required to engage with the specialised games tech modules which will follow in subsequent years. During the second year, you will write code that integrates with networks and operating systems; you will complete modules focused on game programming and 3D asset creation and will be guided through advanced maths and graphical programming techniques. You will also work as part of a team to develop a major project, often by applying game technology to the design of solutions to real-world problems. Many students integrate these projects with competitions or networking events like Global Game Jam or the Microsoft Imagine cup. In']
ground_truth: The Computer Science - Games Technology BSc (Hons) program begins with no prior knowledge of computer programming, accepting students from diverse academic backgrounds. It starts by teaching Python before transitioning to C++ to develop technical skills for specialized games tech modules in subsequent years. In the second year, students work on code integration with networks and operating systems, game programming, 3D asset creation, advanced maths, and graphical programming techniques. They also collaborate on major projects that apply game technology to real-world problem solutions, often participating in competitions or events like Global Game Jam or the Microsoft Imagine Cup.

answer: In a Computer Science - Games Technology BSc (Hons) program, studying artificial intelligence (AI) plays a significant role, especially during the final year of the degree. The focus of AI in this program is to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for creating intelligent computer systems and emerging smart technologies.  During the final year, students will have the opportunity to apply their understanding of AI to various aspects of game development, such as developing AI-powered non-player characters (NPCs), implementing machine learning algorithms for gameplay optimization, and exploring cognitive computing applications in gaming.  Moreover, the program emphasizes the importance of combining a solid foundation in traditional computer science with specialized games technology knowledge, allowing students to keep their options open regarding jobs and career paths in the games industry. Graduates of this program are just as likely to move into well-paid careers in game development, AI research, and other related fields.
contexts: ['Within Computer Science - Games Technology (with foundation year) BSc (Hons) we assume no prior knowledge of computer programming and accept students from a wide range of academic backgrounds. We will provide all the help and support you need to develop and succeed as a coder. Beginning with Python but moving rapidly to C++ will equip you with the technical skills required to engage with the specialised games tech modules which will follow in subsequent years. During the second year, you will write code that integrates with networks and operating systems; you will complete modules focused on game programming and 3D asset creation and will be guided through advanced maths and graphical programming techniques. You will also work as part of a team to develop a major project, often by applying game technology to the design of solutions to real-world problems. Many students integrate these projects with competitions or networking events like Global Game Jam or the Microsoft Imagine cup. In', 'Imagine cup. In your final year, around one-third of your time will be spent working on your major project; this is a great opportunity to focus and specialise in a chosen area of interest with recent projects as diverse as advanced visual FX techniques, EEG mind control of games and games for rehabilitation and therapy. You can also study modules on virtual reality, Mobile app development, physics simulation, serious games and artificial intelligence, including the Microsoft Certified Azure AI fundamentals course available to all our students.']
ground_truth: Studying artificial intelligence plays a significant role in a Computer Science - Games Technology BSc (Hons) program, especially during the final year. Students have the opportunity to delve into advanced AI topics such as serious games and potentially explore areas like EEG mind control of games. Additionally, they can take advantage of courses like Microsoft Certified Azure AI fundamentals, which may further enhance their understanding and application of artificial intelligence in game development.

answer: The Computer Science (Games Technology) BSc program, especially for students without prior computer programming knowledge, focuses on building a foundation of core computer science and software engineering skills during its first year. Here are some key components and skills taught:  1. Core Computer Science and Software Engineering Skills: These include fundamental concepts such as algorithms, data structures, and programming principles. Students will learn these skills primarily through Python, but they will transition to C++ later in the program.  2. Mathematics: Basic mathematical concepts are essential for understanding complex computer science theories and solving problems. Topics may include linear algebra, calculus, and statistics.  3. Engineering Principles: Students will learn engineering principles applicable to software development, such as design patterns, software architecture, and testing methodologies.  4. Introduction to Games Technology: As the program is focused on games technology, students will also receive an introduction to game development, including topics like game engines, game physics, and game design principles.  5. Support and Guidance: The program provides all the necessary help and support for students to develop and succeed as coders, ensuring that students without prior programming experience can still thrive in the program.  6. Collaboration Opportunities: Students will have opportunities to collaborate with other computer games students throughout the country through the university's Computer Society, fostering a vibrant community of like-minded individuals.  7. Foundation Year Option: For students with limited prior knowledge of computer programming, there is also a foundation year option available, providing additional support and guidance to help students develop and succeed as coders.

Starting with Python but quickly progressing to C++, the curriculum is designed for those without prior programming knowledge. The key components and skills taught include fundamental programming concepts, technical skills required for specialized games tech modules in subsequent years, teamwork through major project development that often applies game technology to real-world problem design.

answer: The BSc (Hons) Computing (FT) course offers several opportunities for practical experience and career development, particularly in terms of work placements. Here are some key points:  1. Practical Skills Development: The course is highly practical, providing a strong grounding in computing fundamentals such as programming, maths, and engineering.  2. Involvement in Projects: Students will have the opportunity to be involved in practical projects throughout their studies, which can help build a portfolio of work and demonstrate practical skills to potential employers.  3. Work Placements: The course includes opportunities for work placements, allowing students to gain real-world experience in a professional setting. This can help students apply the theoretical knowledge they've learned in a practical context, and can also increase their chances of employment upon graduation.  4. Employment Statistics: According to the Graduate Outcomes Survey 2020/21, 100% of BSc (Hons) Computing (FT) students were in work or further study 15 months after graduation. Additionally, 96% of students were positive about the academic support on their course (NSS2023). These statistics suggest that the course is effective in preparing students for the job market.
contexts: ['Within Computing BSc (Hons), weâ€™ll give you the best of both worlds by bringing together internet-based development with computing skills vital to supporting businesses. Youâ€™ll have the perfect combination of theory and practice as you explore Internet technologies, database systems and application developmentâ€“ all backed up with lots of practical experiences. Develop your practical skills by taking part in multimedia and virtual reality projects. Our graduates are knowledgeable about the development of software and able to design and manage complex information systems. This course is accredited by the BCS, The Chartered Institute for IT to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status. You will have the opportunity to do a year long paid work placement. Recent examples have included Hewlett Packard and Siemens. \n\n100% of our BSc (Hons) Computing (FT) students were in work or further study 15 months after graduation (Graduate Outcomes Survey 2020/21)']
ground_truth: The BSc (Hons) Computing (FT) course offers various opportunities for practical experience and career development. Students can develop their practical skills through multimedia and virtual reality projects. Additionally, the course provides a year-long paid work placement opportunity, with recent examples including Hewlett Packard and Siemens. This hands-on experience is valuable in preparing graduates to design and manage complex information systems.

answer: Participating in the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals program as part of your studies offers several benefits:  1. **Practical Experience**: The program provides hands-on experience with Azure AI services, helping students gain practical skills that are highly valued by employers.  2. **Certification**: Upon successful completion of the program, students receive a Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals certificate, which is a valuable addition to their CV. This certification demonstrates to potential employers that they have a foundational understanding of Azure AI and its applications.  3. **Cost Savings**: Microsoft sponsors the cloud subscription, course materials, and certification test fees for students, making it a cost-effective way to learn about Azure AI.  4. **Industry Alignment**: The program is designed in collaboration with industry experts, ensuring that the curriculum aligns with current industry practices and trends. This helps students stay updated with the latest developments in AI and technology.  5. **Broader Skillset**: By studying modules such as machine learning, natural language processing, problem-solving, and other cognitive techniques, students develop a comprehensive skillset that is essential for a career in AI. Additionally, understanding the professional and ethical considerations surrounding AI is crucial for navigating the complex landscape of this rapidly evolving field.

ground_truth: Participating in the Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals program offers several benefits for students. Firstly, it provides access to instructor-led training combined with online materials on the Microsoft Learn platform, offering a comprehensive learning experience. Additionally, Microsoft sponsors cloud subscription costs, course materials, and certification test fees at no cost to the student. Upon completion of the program, students receive a valuable Microsoft Azure AI Fundamentals certificate upon graduation. This certificate can significantly enhance a student's career prospects by demonstrating their proficiency in artificial intelligence fundamentals and cloud computing skills, making them more attractive candidates for employment opportunities in tech-related fields.

answer: Some examples of real-world industrial applications that demonstrate the use of computational intelligence include:  1. Predictive Maintenance: Using machine learning algorithms to analyze sensor data from machinery to predict when maintenance is required, reducing downtime and improving efficiency. 2. Fraud Detection: Utilizing AI and machine learning to detect fraudulent activities in financial transactions, such as credit card fraud or insurance claims. 3. Autonomous Vehicles: Implementing AI and deep learning to enable self-driving cars to navigate roads safely and efficiently. 4. Personalized Medicine: Applying AI and machine learning to analyze patient data and genetic information to create personalized treatment plans for diseases like cancer. 5. Smart Cities: Integrating AI and IoT devices to optimize traffic flow, energy consumption, waste management, and public safety in urban environments. 6. Natural Language Processing (NLP): Leveraging AI and machine learning to improve voice assistants, chatbots, and translation services, making communication easier across languages and platforms. 7. Recommendation Systems: Using AI and machine learning to analyze user behavior and preferences to deliver personalized recommendations for products, services, and content. 8. Cybersecurity: Employing AI and machine learning to detect and respond to cyber threats, protecting sensitive data and infrastructure from unauthorized access. 9. Agricultural Automation: Implementing AI and robotics to automate farming tasks, such as planting, watering, and harvesting crops, increasing productivity and reducing labor costs. 10. Supply Chain Optimization: Utilizing AI and machine learning to forecast demand, manage inventory, and optimize logistics, improving efficiency and reducing costs in supply chain management.

ground_truth: Some examples of real-world industrial applications demonstrating the use of computational intelligence include predictive maintenance in manufacturing, where AI algorithms forecast equipment failures to prevent downtimes; supply chain optimization, using machine learning to improve logistics and inventory management; personalized medicine, employing data analysis for tailored treatment plans; autonomous vehicles that rely on computer vision and decision-making algorithms; and financial market analysis, utilizing AI for high-frequency trading strategies.

Unit(s) of assessment: Computer Science and Informatics

School: School of Science and Technology	 

Overview

The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world, and the promotion of their mental wellbeing. The Interactive Systems Research Group  is led by Professor David Brown. This is a

challenges presented by big data and artificial intelligence? Our curriculum will empower you to develop data-driven solutions that optimize business processes, as well as harness the power of data to support human decision-making. But our approach goes beyond theory. You will have hands-on
answer: NTU focuses on combining industry needs with AI predictions in its data science courses primarily through the "Become an Expert in Data Science" program. This program equips students with a strong foundation in computer science, allowing them to extract valuable insights from big data and apply these insights to various industry sectors. The course offers practical experience, focusing on the industrial application of computational intelligence, preparing students to actively engage in industrial, commercial, and technological research and development of intelligent systems. This approach ensures that the education provided by NTU is relevant to current industry demands and prepares students for success in the ever-evolving field of data science.

ground_truth: NTU combines industry needs with AI predictions in its data science courses through a practical approach that prepares students to engage in industrial, commercial, scientific, and technological research and development of intelligent systems. This focus is evident as the context emphasizes real-world scenarios and the application of computational intelligence.
